% Configuring IP routing on a LAN subinterface is only allowed if that subinterface is already configured as part of an IEEE 802.10, IEEE 802.1Q, or ISL vLAN.
options: The gig0/0 interface does not support inter-VLAN routing.
The no shutdown command has not been configured.
The IP address on CiscoVille is incorrect.
The encapsulation dot1Q 20 command has not been configured.
questions.explanation: The steps to configure inter-VLAN routing must be completed in a specific order. Before configuring an IP address on a subinterface, the 'encapsulation dot1q VLAN_id' command must be specified first. The error message indicates that the subinterface gig0/0.20 needs the encapsulation command before an IP address can be assigned.

questions.question:
Refer to the exhibit. A network administrator needs to configure router-on-a-stick for the networks that are shown. How many subinterfaces will have to be created on the router if each VLAN that is shown is to be routed and each VLAN has its own subinterface?
Network topology shows:
- VLAN 7: 172.16.7.2/28
- PC: 10.1.4.3/29
- IP Phone: 10.1.4.18/28
- Printer: 10.1.5.76/24
questions.explanation: Based on the IP addresses and masks given, the PC, printer, IP phone, and switch management VLAN are all on different VLANs. This situation will require four subinterfaces on the router.

questions.question: A network administrator needs to configure router-on-a-stick for a network showing: a switch with VLAN 7 (172.16.7.2/28), a PC (10.1.4.3/29), a printer (10.1.5.76/24), and an IP phone (10.1.4.18/28). How many subinterfaces will have to be created on the router if each VLAN is to be routed and each VLAN has its own subinterface?
questions.explanation: Based on the IP addresses and subnet masks given, the PC (10.1.4.3/29), printer (10.1.5.76/24), IP phone (10.1.4.18/28), and switch management VLAN (172.16.7.2/28) are all on different subnets/VLANs. This situation will require four subinterfaces on the router, one for each VLAN.

questions.question: When routing a large number of VLANs, what are two disadvantages of using the router-on-a-stick inter-VLAN routing method rather than the multilayer switch inter-VLAN routing method? (Choose two.)
options: Router-on-a-stick requires subinterfaces to be configured on the same subnets.
Router-on-a-stick requires multiple physical interfaces on a router.
Multiple subinterfaces may impact the traffic flow speed.
questions.explanation: With the router-on-a-stick inter-VLAN routing method, a dedicated router is required. It only needs one physical interface on the router to route traffic among multiple VLANs, by using subinterfaces on one physical interface. On the other hand, since traffic of all VLANs will have to go through the same physical interfaces, the throughput will be impacted. Also, a multilayer switch can use multiple SVIs to perform inter-VLAN routing.

questions.question: When routing a large number of VLANs, what are two disadvantages of using the router-on-a-stick inter-VLAN routing method rather than the multilayer switch inter-VLAN routing method? (Choose two.)
options: Router-on-a-stick requires subinterfaces to be configured on the same subnets.
Router-on-a-stick requires multiple physical interfaces on a router.
Multiple subinterfaces may impact the traffic flow speed.
questions.explanation: With the router-on-a-stick inter-VLAN routing method, a dedicated router is required, which adds to the equipment cost. Since traffic of all VLANs will have to go through the same physical interface, the throughput will be impacted as the number of VLANs increases. A multilayer switch can use multiple SVIs to perform inter-VLAN routing without these limitations.
The current explanation is sufficient as it clearly states that the default gateway is the IP address of the router interface on the same network as the sending host.
options: The logical address of the router interface on the same network as the host computer
The physical address of the switch interface connected to the host computer
The physical address of the router interface on the same network as the host computer
The logical address assigned to the switch interface connected to the router
questions.question: Which characteristic describes the default gateway of a host computer?

questions.explanation:
In networking, the default gateway is the path used to reach any destination that is not on the local subnet.
  • If a computer can communicate with local devices, it proves that the Physical layer (cable), Data Link layer (MAC addresses/Switching), and Network layer (IP address/Subnet mask) are functioning correctly for local traffic.
  • However, to reach a "remote" network, the computer must send its packets to the router (gateway). If the default gateway address is missing or incorrect, the computer will not know where to send traffic destined for the outside world, effectively "trapping" it within its own local network.
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • The cable is not connected properly: If the cable were disconnected, the computer could not access any devices, including those on the same network.
  • The computer has an invalid IP address: If the IP address were completely invalid (e.g., 0.0.0.0 or a duplicated IP), local communication would likely fail as well.
  • The computer has an incorrect subnet mask: An incorrect subnet mask usually causes the computer to either misidentify a local host as remote (sending it to the gateway) or a remote host as local (trying to reach it via ARP). This would cause inconsistent local and remote issues, rather than just blocking all remote access.
options: The cable is not connected properly to the NIC.
The computer has an invalid IP address.
The computer has an incorrect subnet mask.
The computer has an invalid default gateway address.
questions.question: A computer can access devices on the same network but cannot access devices on other networks. What is the probable cause of this problem?

questions.explanation: When a host needs to send a message to another host located on the same network, it can forward the message directly. However, when a host needs to send a message to a remote network, it must use the router, also known as the default gateway. This is because the data link frame address of the remote destination host cannot be used directly. Instead, the IP packet has to be sent to the router (default gateway) and the router will forward the packet toward its destination. Therefore, if the default gateway is incorrectly configured, the host can communicate with other hosts on the same network, but not with hosts on remote networks.
options: The host cannot communicate with other hosts in the local network.
The switch will not forward packets initiated by the host.
The host will have to use ARP to determine the correct address of the default gateway.
The host cannot communicate with hosts in other networks.
A ping from the host to 127.0.0.1 would not be successful.
questions.question: What will happen if the default gateway address is incorrectly configured on a host?

questions.explanation: The default gateway is the IP address of an interface on the router on the same network as the sending host. Looking at the router configuration, the Payroll LAN is connected to the router via the gi0/0 interface with IP address 10.27.14.148 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0. When a host needs to communicate with remote networks, it must send packets to the default gateway (the router interface) on the same local network. Therefore, the default gateway address configured on the new host should be 10.27.14.148, which is the IP address of the router interface on the Payroll LAN.
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. A network administrator is connecting a new host to the Payroll LAN. The host needs to communicate with remote networks. What IP address would be configured as the default gateway on the new host?

questions.explanation: Topic 11.1.0 - The subnet mask of 255.255.255.0 has 8 host bits. The mask of 255.255.255.128 results in 7 host bits. The mask of 255.255.255.224 has 5 host bits. Finally, 255.255.255.240 represents 4 host bits.
questions.question: Which subnet mask would be used if 5 host bits are available?

questions.explanation: Topic 11.1.0 - A /27 mask is the same as 255.255.255.224. This leaves 5 host bits. With 5 host bits, 32 IP addresses are possible, but one address represents the subnet number and one address represents the broadcast address. Thus, 30 addresses can then be used to assign to network devices.
questions.question: How many usable IP addresses are available on the 192.168.1.0/27 network?

questions.explanation: The subnet mask of 255.255.255.224 has 5 host bits. The mask of 255.255.255.128 results in 7 host bits. The mask of 255.255.255.240 has 4 host bits. Finally, 255.255.255.248 represents 3 host bits.
questions.question: Which subnet mask would be used if exactly 4 host bits are available?

questions.explanation: Topic 11.8.0 - The subnet mask 255.255.255.224 is equivalent to the /27 prefix. This leaves 5 bits for hosts, providing a total of 30 usable IP addresses (2^5 = 32 - 2 = 30).
questions.question: A network administrator is variably subnetting a network. The smallest subnet has a mask of 255.255.255.224. How many usable host addresses will this subnet provide?

questions.explanation: The ging command is used to test connectivity between hosts. The other options describe tasks not performed by ping. Pinging the default gateway will test whether the host has the capability to reach hosts on its own network and on other networks.
options: To obtain a dynamic IP address from the server
To request that gateway forward the connection request to the file server
To test that the host has the capability to reach hosts on other networks
To resolve the domain name of the file server to its IP address
questions.question: A user who is unable to connect to the file server contacts the help desk. The helpdesk technician asks the user to ping the IP address of the default gateway that is configured on the workstation. What is the purpose for this ping command?

questions.explanation: Addresses 10.16.10.0 through 10.16.10.63 are taken for the leftmost network. Addresses 10.16.10.192 through 10.16.10.207 are used by the center network. The address space from 208-255 assumes a /28 mask, which does not allow enough host bits to accommodate 25 host addresses. The address ranges that are available include 10.16.10.64/26 and10.16.10.128/26. To accommodate 25 hosts, 5 host bits are needed, so a /27 mask is necessary. Four possible /27 subnets could be created from the available addresses between 10.16.10.64 and 10.16.10.191: 10.16.10.64/27
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. Considering the addresses already used and having to remain within the 10.16.10.0/24 network range, which subnet address could be assigned to the network containing 25 hosts?

questions.explanation: A /26 mask is the same as 255.255.255.192. The mask leaves 6 host bits. With 6 host bits, 64 IP addresses are possible. One address represents the subnet number and one address represents the broadcast address, which means that 62 addresses can then be used to assign to network devices.
questions.question: What is the usable number of host IP addresses on a network that has a /26 mask?

questions.explanation: With a network prefix of 48, there will be 16 bits available for subnetting because the interface ID starts at bit 64. Sixteen bits will yield 65536 subnets.
questions.question: A network administrator has received the IPv6 prefix 2001:DB8::/48 for subnetting. Assuming the administrator does not subnet into the interface ID portion of the address space, how many subnets can the administrator create from the /48 prefix?

questions.explanation: For the subnet of 192.168.1.64/26, there are 6 bits for host addresses, yielding 64 possible addresses. However, the first and last subnets are the network and broadcast addresses for this subnet. Therefore, the range of host addresses for this subnet is 192.168.1.65 to 192.168.1.126. The other subnets do not contain the address 192.168.1.96 as a valid host address.
questions.question: Which subnet would include the address 192.168.1.96 as a usable host address?

questions.explanation:
In a TCP three-way handshake, the two flags used to establish a connection are SYN (Synchronize) and ACK (Acknowledgment).The process follows these three steps:
  1. SYN: The client sends a packet with the SYN flag set to initiate a connection and synchronize sequence numbers.
  2. SYN-ACK: The server responds with a packet that has both the SYN and ACK flags set, acknowledging the client's request and sending its own synchronization sequence.
  3. ACK: The client sends a final packet with the ACK flag set to acknowledge the server's sequence number, completing the connection establishment.

Why the other options are incorrect:
  • FIN (Finish): This flag is used to terminate a connection gracefully. Itâ€™s the opposite of SYN; it says, "I have no more data to send, let's close this session."
  • RST (Reset): This is used when a connection needs to be closed abruptly or if a device receives a packet for a connection that doesn't exist. Itâ€™s a way of saying, "Something is wrong, kill this connection immediately."
  • PSH (Push): This flag tells the receiving device to pass the data to the application layer immediately rather than waiting for the buffer to fill up. It is used during data transfer, not during the initial handshake.
  • URG (Urgent): This indicates that certain data within the segment is urgent and should be processed before other data. Like PSH, this is used during the actual exchange of data, not to set up the connection.
questions.question: Which two flags in the TCP header are used in a TCP three-way handshake to establish connectivity between two network devices? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: In networks today, a failed ping could mean that the other devices on the network are blocking pings. Further investigation such as checking network connectivity from other devices on the same network is warranted.
options: The NIC in the PC is bad.
The TCP/IP protocol is not enabled.
The router that is attached to the same network as the workstation is down.
Nothing can be determined for sure at this point.

In networks today, a failed ping could mean that the other devices on the network are blocking pings. Further investigation such as checking network connectivity from other devices on the same network is warranted.
questions.question: A user reports a lack of network connectivity. The technician takes control of the user machine and attempts to ping other computers on the network and these pings fail. The technician pings the default gateway and that also fails. What can be determined for sure by the results of these tests?

questions.explanation: The default gateway is the IP address of a router interface on the same network segment as the sending host. This interface serves as the exit point for any traffic destined to remote networks that are not on the local network. Looking at the router configuration for the Floor router, the Registrar LAN is connected to the router via interface gi0/1 with an IP address of 192.168.235.234 and a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0. When a new host is added to the Registrar LAN and needs to communicate with remote networks (such as the Manager LAN, ISP, or Head Office WAN), it must be configured with the default gateway IP address that corresponds to the router interface on that same network. This ensures that any packets destined for remote networks are forwarded to the router for proper routing. Therefore, the default gateway for the new host on the Registrar LAN should be configured as 192.168.235.234, which is the IP address of the Floor router's gi0/1 interface (the gateway interface on the Registrar LAN).
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. A network administrator is connecting a new host to the Registrar LAN. The host needs to communicate with remote networks. What IP address would be configured as the default gateway on the new host?

questions.explanation: With an IPv4 network, the subnet mask is determined by the hosts bits that are required: 11 host bits required - 255.255.248.0 10 host bits required - 255.255.252.0 9 host bits required - 255.255.254.0 8 host bits required - 255.255.255.0 7 host bits required - 255.255.255.128 6 host bits required - 255.255.255.192 5 host bits required - 255.255.255.224 4 host bits required - 255.255.255.240 3 host bits required - 255.255.255.248 2 host bits required - 255.255.255.252
questions.question: Given network 172.18.109.0, which subnet mask would be used if 6 host bits were available?
Which router bootup sequence is correct?

1 - perform the POST and load the startup configuration file, 2 - locate and load the bootstrap program, 3 - locate and load the Cisco IOS software
1 - perform the POST and load the bootstrap program, 2 - locate and load the Cisco IOS software, 3 - locate and load the startup configuration file or enter setup mode
questions.explanation: When a router is powered on, it undergoes a POST to verify that the hardware is functional. After POST, the bootstrap program is loaded, which then locates and loads the Cisco IOS software. Finally, the startup configuration file is loaded if one is present, otherwise the router enters setup mode.

questions.question: A network administrator is connecting a new host to the Payroll LAN (interface gi0/0 with IP 10.27.14.148/24). The host needs to communicate with remote networks. What IP address would be configured as the default gateway on the new host?
questions.explanation: The default gateway for hosts on a LAN is the IP address of the router interface connected to that LAN. Since the Payroll LAN is connected to router interface gi0/0 with IP address 10.27.14.148, this is the address that should be configured as the default gateway on the new host.

questions.question: A network administrator is connecting a new host to the Registrar LAN (interface gi0/1 with IP 192.168.235.234/24). The host needs to communicate with remote networks. What IP address would be configured as the default gateway on the new host?
questions.explanation: The default gateway for hosts on a LAN is the IP address of the router interface connected to that LAN. Since the Registrar LAN is connected to router interface gi0/1 with IP address 192.168.235.234, this is the address that should be configured as the default gateway on the new host.

questions.question: Which router bootup sequence is correct?
options: 1 - perform the POST and load the Cisco IOS software, 2 - locate and load the startup configuration file or enter setup mode, 3 - locate and load the bootstrap program
1 - perform the POST and load the bootstrap program, 2 - locate and load the startup configuration file or enter setup mode, 3 - locate and load the Cisco IOS software
1 - perform the POST and load the startup configuration file, 2 - locate and load the bootstrap program, 3 - locate and load the Cisco IOS software
1 - perform the POST and load the bootstrap program, 2 - locate and load the Cisco IOS software, 3 - locate and load the startup configuration file or enter setup mode
questions.explanation: When a router is powered on, it undergoes a POST to verify that the hardware is functional, after which it proceeds by locating and loading the Cisco IOS software and then loading the startup configuration file if one is present.

NAT (Network Address Translation) typically uses one-to-one IP address mappings, while PAT (Port Address Translation), also called NAT overload, allows many internal private IP addresses to be mapped to a single public IP address by using different port numbers to track each session. PAT is the most common form of NAT used in home and small business networks because it conserves public IPv4 addresses. Both NAT and PAT translate IP addresses and can translate port numbers.
options: NAT translates IP addresses, PAT translates port numbers
NAT uses one-to-one mappings, PAT allows many-to-one mappings using port numbers
NAT is used for IPv4, PAT is used for IPv6
NAT is bidirectional, PAT is unidirectional
questions.question: What is the primary difference between NAT and PAT (NAT overload)?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 2, Chapter 10

questions.explanation: The DHCP four-way handshake consists of: (1) DHCP Discover - client broadcasts to find DHCP servers, (2) DHCP Offer - server offers an IP address, (3) DHCP Request - client requests the offered IP, (4) DHCP Acknowledge (ACK) - server acknowledges and leases the IP. This is often abbreviated as DORA (Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge). DHCP Renew is a separate process that occurs when a client wants to extend its lease.
questions.question: Which two messages are part of the DHCP four-way handshake? (Choose two)
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 2, Chapter 12

questions.explanation: Syslog severity levels range from 0 (most severe) to 7 (least severe). Level 0 (Emergency) indicates the system is unusable. The complete list is: 0-Emergency, 1-Alert, 2-Critical, 3-Error, 4-Warning, 5-Notification, 6-Informational, 7-Debugging. A common mnemonic is 'Every Awesome Cisco Engineer Will Need Ice-cream Daily'. When configuring logging, specifying a level includes that level and all more severe levels.
questions.question: In Syslog, which severity level indicates an emergency condition where the system is unusable?

questions.explanation: The 'ip helper-address [server-ip]' command configures a router interface to forward DHCP (and other UDP broadcast) requests to a specified server in a different subnet. This is necessary because DHCP Discover messages are broadcasts, which routers don't forward by default. The helper address converts the broadcast to a unicast destined for the DHCP server. This allows centralized DHCP servers to service multiple subnets.
options: To assign a static IP address to the interface
To forward broadcast DHCP requests to a DHCP server in a different subnet
To configure the router as a DHCP server
To enable DHCP snooping on the interface
questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'ip helper-address' command on a router interface?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 2, Chapter 12

questions.explanation: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) automatically assigns IP addresses and other network configuration parameters to devices on a network, allowing them to communicate effectively.
options: Automatic assignment of an IP address to each host
Translation of IP addresses to domain names
questions.question: Which functionality is provided by DHCP?

questions.explanation: DNS, DHCP, and FTP are all application layer protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite. ARP and PPP are network access layer protocols, and NAT is an internet layer protocol in the TCP/IP protocol suite.
questions.question: What three application layer protocols are part of the TCP/IP protocol suite? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: Store-and forward switching accepts the entire frame and performs error checking using CRC before forwarding the frame. Store-and-forward is often required for QOS analysis. Fast-forward and fragment-free are both variations of the cut-through switching method where only part of the frame is received before the switch begins to forward it.
questions.question: What are two examples of the cut-through switching method? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: LLDP (Link Layer Discovery Protocol) is an industry-standard, vendor-neutral discovery protocol defined in IEEE 802.1AB. It serves the same purpose as CDP but works with devices from multiple vendors. Both protocols allow network devices to advertise information about themselves to directly connected neighbors. STP is Spanning Tree Protocol, VTP is VLAN Trunking Protocol, and DTP is Dynamic Trunking Protocol.
questions.question: Which discovery protocol is a vendor-neutral alternative to Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP)?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 10

questions.explanation: The two main functions of the ARP protocol are to resolve an IPv4 address to a MAC address and to maintain an ARP table, which lists the resolved pairs of IPv4 address and MAC address. A device automatically obtains an IP address through DHCP. The functions of DNS include resolving (or mapping) a domain name with its IP address and maintaining a table for the domain name/IP pairs.
options: Mapping a domain name to its IP address
Resolving an IPv4 address to a MAC address
Maintaining a table of domain names with their resolved IP addresses
questions.question: What is one function of the ARP protocol?

questions.explanation:
The Time-to-Live (TTL) field is an 8-bit value in the IPv4 header designed to prevent packets from looping indefinitely on a network (which could happen due to incorrect routing configurations).When a packet is created, the source host sets an initial TTL value (e.g., 64, 128, or 255). Every time the packet arrives at a router, that router decrements the TTL value by 1 before forwarding it. If the TTL reaches 0, the router discards the packet and usually sends an ICMP "Time Exceeded" message back to the source.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Sequence Number: This field exists in the TCP header (Layer 4), not the IPv4 header. It is used to reassemble data segments in the correct order.
  • Acknowledgment Number: This is also a TCP header field used to confirm the receipt of data.
  • Differentiated Services (DiffServ): This field is used for Quality of Service (QoS) to prioritize certain types of traffic (like voice or video) over others; it does not handle packet lifetime or loop prevention.
questions.question: Which field in the IPv4 header is used to prevent a packet from traversing a network endlessly?

questions.explanation: The default gateway is configured on a switch primarily to enable the switch itself to communicate with devices on remote networks. This is essential for tasks like logging, network management (e.g., SNMP), and other network services that the switch might need to perform outside of its local VLAN or network segment.
options: Hosts that are connected to the switch can use the switch default gateway address to forward packets to a remote destination.
A switch must have a default gateway to be accessible by Telnet and SSH.
The default gateway address is used to forward packets originating from the switch to remote networks.
It provides a next-hop address for all traffic that flows through the switch.

A default gateway address allows a switch to forward packets that originate on the switch to remote networks. A default gateway address on a switch does not provide Layer 3 routing for PCs that are connected on that switch. A switch can still be accessible from Telnet as long as the source of the Telnet connection is on the local network.
questions.question: Within a production network, what is the purpose of configuring a switch with a default gateway address?

questions.explanation:
To send data to a destination on a different network (like a web server on the Internet), a PC must send the packets to its Default Gateway.In the typical network topology associated with this question, the PC is located on the 172.20.0.0/24 network. The Default Gateway is the IP address of the router interface (usually labeled G0/0 or Fa0/0) that is directly connected to the local switch.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • 172.24.255.17 / 172.24.1.22: These are typically addresses of remote servers or internal interfaces further "up" the network hierarchy (like a DNS server or a Serial interface).
  • 172.24.255.4: This often represents a remote destination or an intermediate hop in the routing table.
  • 172.20.1.18: This would be a device on a different local subnet (VLAN), but it is not the gateway interface for the PC's own subnet.
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. A user PC has successfully transmitted packets to www.cisco.com. Which IP address does the user PC target in order to forward its data off the local network?

questions.explanation: NTP (Network Time Protocol) is used to synchronize the clocks on network devices. Accurate time synchronization is crucial for correlating log entries across multiple devices, certificate validation, and time-based access control. NTP uses a hierarchical system of time sources called strata, where stratum 0 devices are atomic clocks or GPS clocks, stratum 1 devices sync with stratum 0, and so on. NTP uses UDP port 123.
options: To synchronize clocks on network devices
To resolve domain names to IP addresses
questions.question: What is the purpose of Network Time Protocol (NTP)?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 2, Chapter 8

questions.explanation: The ging command is used to verify connectivity to a device,the commands ipconfig /flushdns will cause the adapter to flush the DNS cache, while ipconfig /displaydns will result in the display of the DNS information in the cache.
questions.question: A technician is troubleshooting a network where it is suspected that a defective node in the network path is causing packets to be dropped. The technician only has the IP address of the end point device and does not have any details of the intermediate devices. What command can the technician use to identify the faulty node?

questions.explanation:
The Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is a network-layer protocol specifically designed to communicate the status of the network. While the Internet Protocol (IP) is responsible for delivering data, it does not have a built-in mechanism for error reporting. ICMP fills this gap by providing a standardized feedback loop.When a router or a destination host encounters a problem while processing an IP packetâ€”such as the destination being unreachable or the packet's lifetime (TTL) expiringâ€”it generates an ICMP error message and sends it back to the source IP address of the original packet.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • ARP (Address Resolution Protocol): Used to map a known IP address to a MAC address on the local network. It does not handle error reporting for packet delivery.
  • BOOTP (Bootstrap Protocol): An older precursor to DHCP used by network nodes to obtain an IP address from a configuration server.
  • DNS (Domain Name System): Resolves human-readable domain names (like www.cisco.com) into IP addresses. It is not involved in reporting delivery failures of individual packets.
questions.question: Which protocol provides feedback from the destination host to the source host about errors in packet delivery?

questions.explanation: SLAAC uses ICMPv6, specifically the Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP), to allow devices to automatically configure their own IPv6 addresses without the need for a DHCP server.
questions.question: Which protocol supports Stateless Address Autoconfiguration (SLAAC) for dynamic assignment of IPv6 addresses to a host?

questions.explanation: Both DNS and VoIP use UDP to provide low overhead services within a network implementation. DNS uses UDP for quick query responses, while VoIP uses it for real-time audio transmission.
questions.question: Which two services or protocols use the preferred UDP protocol for fast transmission and low overhead? (Choose two)

questions.explanation: On a home network, the home router usually serves as the DHCP server, dynamically assigning IPv4 addresses to clients.
questions.question: On a home network, which device is most likely to provide dynamic IPv4 addressing to clients on the home network?

questions.explanation: The explanation is sufficient as it correctly identifies '.com' as the top-level domain.
questions.question: What part of the URL, http://www.cisco.com/index.html, represents the top-level DNS domain?

questions.explanation:
Email communication generally involves two different types of protocols: those for sending and those for receiving/retrieving.POP3 (Post Office Protocol version 3) is designed specifically to allow an email client (like Microsoft Outlook or Apple Mail) to download or "pull" messages from a remote mail server to the local device. Once the messages are downloaded, they are typically deleted from the server, though modern settings allow for copies to be kept.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol): This is used to send email. It moves mail from a client to a server, or between servers. It is a "push" protocol.
  • SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol): This has nothing to do with email. It is used by administrators to monitor and manage network devices like routers and switches.
  • HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol): While "Webmail" (like Gmail in a browser) uses HTTP to display messages, the underlying protocol defined for transferring mail directly to a dedicated email client in this context is POP3 (or IMAP).
questions.question: Which protocol can be used to transfer messages from an email server to an email client?

questions.explanation: Topic 15.4.0 - Static IPv4 address assignment requires personnel to configure each network host with addresses manually. Large networks can change frequently and have many more hosts to configure than do small networks. DHCP provides a much more efficient means of configuring and managing IPv4 addresses on large networks than does static address assignment.
options: Large networks send more requests for domain to IP address resolution than do smaller networks.
DHCP uses a reliable transport layer protocol.
It prevents sharing of files that are copyrighted.
It is a more efficient way to manage IPv4 addresses than static address assignment is.
Hosts on large networks require more IPv4 addressing configuration settings than do hosts on small networks.
questions.question: Why is DHCP for IPv4 preferred for use on large networks?

questions.explanation:
The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is the standard protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses and other network configuration information (such as subnet masks, default gateways, and DNS server addresses) to devices on a network.When a wireless host (like a smartphone or laptop) connects to a network, it typically does not have a static IP address. It sends a DHCP Discover broadcast message to find a DHCP server, which then provides an available IP address from its pool.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • FTP (File Transfer Protocol): Used specifically for moving files between a client and a server; it does not handle network addressing.
  • HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol): Used for transferring web page data. You need an IP address already configured before you can use HTTP.
  • ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol): Used for sending error messages and operational information (like Pings); it cannot assign IP addresses.
  • SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol): Used by administrators to monitor and manage network device performance, not for client IP assignment.
questions.question: A wireless host needs to request an IPv4 address. What protocol would be used to process the request?

questions.explanation: Two important functions of DNS are to (1) provide IP addresses for domain names such as www.cisco.com, and (2) forward requests that cannot be resolved to other servers in order to provide domain name to IP address translation. DHCP provides IP addressing information to local devices. A file transfer protocol such as FTP, SFTP, or TFTP provides file sharing services. IMAP or POP can be used to retrieve an email message from a server.
options: Providing IP addresses to local hosts
Allowing data transfer between two network devices
Mapping name-to-IP addresses for internal hosts
Forwarding name resolution requests between servers
questions.question: Which two tasks can be performed by a local DNS server? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation:
Explanation:Application layer protocols choose their Transport Layer protocol (TCP or UDP) based on whether they prioritize reliability or speed. Because TCP provides error recovery, data sequencing, and connection management, it is used by applications where data integrity is critical.Why these are correct:
  • SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol): Used for sending emails. It requires TCP to ensure that every part of an email message arrives intact and in the correct order.
  • FTP (File Transfer Protocol): Used for transferring files. Since even a single missing bit can corrupt a file, FTP relies on TCP for guaranteed delivery.
  • HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol): Used for web browsing. TCP ensures that all elements of a webpage (text, formatting, images) are received completely.
Why the other options are wrong:
  • SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol): Typically uses UDP (Port 161) to minimize network overhead while monitoring devices.
  • TFTP (Trivial File Transfer Protocol): A simplified version of FTP that uses UDP (Port 69). It lacks the sophisticated error-checking of FTP and is used for simple tasks like booting diskless workstations or transferring firmware.
  • DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol): Uses UDP (Ports 67 and 68). Since a device doesn't have an IP address when it starts the DHCP process, it cannot establish a connection-oriented TCP session.
questions.question: Which three application layer protocols use TCP? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: SMTP is the protocol used to send emails from a client to a server or between servers. IMAP is used to retrieve emails from a server, allowing for email management on multiple devices. DNS may assist in resolving server addresses but is not directly involved in the email sending process.
questions.question: Which two protocols may devices use in the application process that sends email? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation:
To solve this, we match the business requirements to their specific Application Layer protocols:
  1. World Wide Web â†’ HTTP: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol is the foundation of data communication for the web. It is used by browsers to request and display web pages.
  2. File Transfer â†’ FTP: The File Transfer Protocol is the standard network protocol used to transfer computer files between a client and a server.
  3. E-mail â†’ SMTP: The Simple Mail Transfer Protocol is the primary protocol used to send (push) e-mail messages from a client to a server or between servers.
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • DNS (Domain Name System): While essential for finding the IP addresses of these services, it is not the protocol that provides the web, file, or email content itself.
  • SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol): This is used by IT staff to monitor and manage the health and performance of network devices (like routers and switches).
  • DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol): This is used to automatically assign IP addresses to devices when they join a network.
questions.question: A manufacturing company subscribes to certain hosted services from its ISP. The services that are required include hosted world wide web, file transfer, and e-mail. Which protocols represent these three key applications? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: MX, or mail exchange messages, are used to map a domain name to several mail exchange servers that all belong to the same domain.
options: the FQDN of the alias used to identify a service
the IP address for an FQDN entry
the domain name mapped to mail exchange servers
the IP address of an authoritative name server
questions.question: What type of information is contained in a DNS MX record?

questions.explanation: When a host configured to use DHCP powers up an a network it sends a DHCPDISCOVER message. FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF is the L2 broadcast address. A DHCP server replies with a unicast DHCPOFFER message back to the host.
options: The source MAC address is 48 ones (FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF).
The message comes from a server offering an IP address.
The message comes from a client seeking an IP address.
All hosts receive the message, but only a DHCP server replies.
Only the DHCP server receives the message.
questions.question: Which three statements describe a DHCP Discover message? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: FTP, DHCP, and POP3 are application layer protocols. TCP and UDP are transport layer protocols. ARP is a network layer protocol.
questions.question: Which three protocols operate at the application layer of the TCP/IP model? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: CDP is a Cisco-proprietary protocol that can be disabled globally by using the 'no cdp run' global configuration command, or disabled on a specific interface by using the 'no cdp enable' interface configuration command. The 'show cdp neighbors detail' command reveals the IP address of a neighboring device regardless of whether you can ping the neighbor.
options: The show cdp neighbor detail command will reveal the IP address of a neighbor only if there is Layer 3 connectivity.
To disable CDP globally, the no cdp enable command in interface configuration mode must be used.
CDP can be disabled globally or on a specific interface.
Because it runs at the data link layer, the CDP protocol can only be implemented in switches.
questions.question: Which statement is true about CDP on a Cisco device?

questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) uses TCP port 22 as its default destination port. When a client wants to establish a secure remote connection to a server using SSH, it must send the initial connection request to port 22 on the destination server. Port 22 is a well-known port (in the range 0-1023) that is reserved specifically for SSH connections. Port 69 is used for TFTP (Trivial File Transfer Protocol), port 67 is used for DHCP servers, and port 80 is used for HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol). Each network service has its own designated port number that allows the server to properly route incoming connection requests to the correct service or application.
questions.question: A client creates a packet to send to a server. The client is requesting SSH service. What number will be used as the destination port number in the sending packet?

questions.explanation: The show cdp neighbors command is used to verify Layer 2 connectivity between directly connected Cisco devices. If a ping fails, it could be due to Layer 3 issues, but CDP can confirm that Layer 1 and Layer 2 are functioning. This command helps ensure that the physical and data link layers are operational, which is crucial for troubleshooting connectivity issues.
options: The network administrator suspects a virus because the ping command did not work.
The network administrator wants to verify Layer 2 connectivity.
The network administrator wants to verify the IP address configured on router R2.
The network administrator wants to determine if connectivity can be established from a non-directly connected network.
questions.question: A ping fails when performed from router R1 to directly connected router R2. The network administrator then proceeds to issue the show cdp neighbors command. Why would the network administrator issue this command if the ping failed between the two routers?

questions.explanation:
Explanation: The extended ping command (initiated by typing ping and pressing Enter in privileged EXEC mode) allows an administrator to specify parameters that are not available in a standard ping.By default, when a router originates a ping, it uses the IP address of the exit interface as the source. In this scenario, the administrator wants to verify connectivity from the perspective of the interface that H3 uses (the Gateway interface on R2). By using an extended ping, the admin can:
  • Manually set the Source address or interface to R2's LAN interface (H3's gateway).
  • Verify if R1 (and the path to H1) has a valid return route to that specific subnet.
  • Prove that R2 is correctly routing traffic originating from the H3 network segment.
If a standard ping from R2 to H1 succeeds but an extended ping sourced from the H3-facing interface fails, it typically indicates a routing issue (e.g., a missing return route on a downstream router) rather than a configuration error on R2's local interfaces.Incorrect Options:
  • traceroute: Useful for finding where a packet is dropped along a path, but by default, it also uses the exit interface IP and doesn't inherently "prove" the source-specific configuration as effectively as a sourced ping.
  • show cdp neighbors: This is a Layer 2 discovery tool. While it proves physical and data-link connectivity to directly connected Cisco devices, it cannot test end-to-end Layer 3 reachability to host H1.
  • telnet: Used for remote management or testing if a specific TCP port is open. It does not provide the granular source-interface control needed to simulate H3's traffic path in this specific context.
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. Host H3 is having trouble communicating with host H1. The network administrator suspects a problem exists with the H3 workstation and wants to prove that there is no problem with the R2 configuration. What tool could the network administrator use on router R2 to prove that communication exists to host H1 from the interface on R2, which is the interface that H3 uses when communicating with remote networks?

questions.explanation: Domain Name System (DNS) is used to translate a web address to an IP address. The address of the DNS server is provided via DHCP to host computers.
questions.question: A user is unable to reach the website when typing http://www.cisco.com in a web browser, but can reach the same site by typing http://72.163.4.161. What is the issue?

questions.explanation: Quality of service (QoS) is a mechanism used to classify and prioritize traffic through the network, enabling devices to minimize latency for real-time applications such as voice and video.
questions.question: What mechanism can be implemented in a small network to help minimize network latency for real-time streaming applications?

questions.explanation: The IP address 169.254.x.x indicates that the PC failed to obtain an IP address from a DHCP server and has self-assigned an Automatic Private IP Addressing (APIPA) address. This suggests that the PC is configured to obtain an IP address automatically via DHCP, but the DHCP server is unreachable. The issue is unrelated to dynamic routing configurations.
options: The PC cannot contact a DHCP server.
The DNS server address is misconfigured.
The default gateway address is not configured.
The PC is configured to obtain an IP address automatically.
The enterprise network is misconfigured for dynamic routing.
questions.question: An employee complains that a Windows PC cannot connect to the Internet. A network technician issues the ipconfig command on the PC and is shown an IP address of 169.254.10.3. Which two conclusions can be drawn? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: The explanation is already clear and accurate, detailing how nslookup helps verify DNS resolution.
questions.question: Users are complaining that they are unable to browse certain websites on the Internet. An administrator can successfully ping a web server via its IP address, but cannot browse to the domain name of the website. Which troubleshooting tool would be most useful in determining where the problem is?

questions.explanation: The nslookup command is used to query DNS servers to obtain domain name or IP address mapping information. The show ipv6 route command is used to display the IPv6 routing table. The show ipv6 interface command is used to display the IPv6 interface information. The copy startup-config running-config command is used to copy the startup configuration to the running configuration.
questions.question: An administrator is troubleshooting connectivity issues and needs to determine the IP address of a website. What is the best command to use to accomplish the task?

questions.explanation:
Explanation: The TCP/IP model is a hierarchical protocol stack developed for practical network implementation, whereas the OSI model is a theoretical framework. The TCP/IP Application layer (Layer 4 in the original model) handles all high-level protocols, issues of representation, encoding, and dialog control. Therefore, it combines the functions of the top three layers of the OSI model:
  • Application Layer (OSI): Directly supports user applications and network services (e.g., HTTP, FTP, DNS).
  • Presentation Layer (OSI): Ensures data is in a usable format and is where data encryption/decryption and compression occur.
  • Session Layer (OSI): Establishes, manages, and terminates connections between local and remote applications.
Incorrect Options:
  • Transport: This layer maps directly to the Transport layer in the TCP/IP model, focusing on host-to-host communication and reliability.
  • Network: Maps to the Internet layer of the TCP/IP model, handling logical addressing and routing.
  • Data link & Physical: These two layers are combined into the Network Access (or Link) layer in the TCP/IP model, dealing with hardware addressing and physical transmission.
questions.question: Which three layers of the OSI model are comparable in function to the application layer of the TCP/IP model? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: IPv6 has a vastly larger address space compared to IPv4, making NAT unnecessary for address conservation. The large number of available IPv6 addresses allows every device to have its own globally unique address, which avoids the NAT-induced application problems experienced by applications that require end-to-end connectivity.
options: Because IPv6 has integrated security, there is no need to hide the IPv6 addresses of internal networks.
Any host or user can get a public IPv6 network address because the number of available IPv6 addresses is extremely large.
The problems that are induced by NAT applications are solved because the IPv6 header improves packet handling by intermediate routers.
The end-to-end connectivity problems that are caused by NAT are solved because the number of routes increases with the number of nodes that are connected to the Internet.

The large number of public IPv6 addresses eliminates the need for NAT. Sites from the largest enterprises to single households can get public IPv6 network addresses. This avoids some of the NAT-induced application problems that are experienced by applications that require end-to-end connectivity.
questions.question: Why is NAT not needed in IPv6?

questions.explanation:
Explanation: The nslookup (Name Server Lookup) command is a network administration tool used to manually query Domain Name System (DNS) servers. It is essential for troubleshooting name resolution issues. Key features include:
  • Manual Querying: Unlike passive resolution, nslookup allows a user to enter a hostname and receive the specific IP address mapped to it directly from the configured DNS server.
  • Interactive and Non-interactive Modes: You can run a single query (e.g., nslookup cisco.com) or enter an interactive shell to perform multiple lookups or change query types (like MX or NS records).
  • Server Specification: You can manually specify which DNS server to query by adding the server's IP after the hostname (e.g., nslookup cisco.com 8.8.8.8), which helps verify if a specific server is providing correct or updated records.
Incorrect Options:
  • ipconfig /displaydns: This command is used to view the local DNS resolver cache on a Windows machine. It shows what has already been resolved recently, but it does not send a new query to a DNS server.
  • tracert: This utility is used to trace the path packets take to a destination. While it may trigger a DNS lookup to show the names of the routers (hops) along the path, its primary purpose is measuring latency and identifying routing bottlenecks, not querying DNS records.
  • net: The net command suite (e.g., net use, net start) is used for managing network resources, users, and services in a Windows environment, but it does not have host-name resolution or DNS querying capabilities.
questions.question: Which command is used to manually query a DNS server to resolve a specific host name?

questions.explanation: The ping command tests the connection between two hosts. When ping uses a host domain name to test the connection, the resolver an the PC will first perform the name resolution to query the DNS server for the IP address of the host. If the ping command is unable to resolve the domain name to an IP address, an error will result. Nslookup is a tool for testing and troubleshooting DNS servers.
questions.question: Which two commands could be used to check if DNS name resolution is working properly on a Windows PC? (Choose two.)

Refer to the exhibit. PC-A is unable to receive an IPv6 address from the stateful DHCPv6 server. What is the problem?

[Configuration shows ipv6 nd managed-config-flag on Gig0/0, but ipv6 dhcp relay destination command on Gig0/1 instead of Gig0/0]
options: The ipv6 nd managed-config-flag command should be ipv6 nd other-config-flag.
The ipv6 nd managed-config-flag should be applied to interface Gig0/1.
The ipv6 dhcp relay command should use the link-local address of the DHCP server.
The ipv6 dhcp relay command should be applied to interface Gig0/0.
questions.explanation: The 'ipv6 dhcp relay' command must be applied to the interface where the clients are located. The 'ipv6 dhcp relay' command can use either the link-local or global unicast address of the DHCPv6 server, or even a multicast address. The 'ipv6 nd managed-config-flag' indicates to the clients that they should use stateful DHCPv6 and is also applied to the interface where the clients are located.

questions.question: If more than one DHCP server is available on the local network, in which order will DHCP messages be sent between a host and a DHCP server?
questions.explanation: The DHCP DORA process consists of four steps: Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledgment. The client first broadcasts a DHCP Discover message to find available servers. Servers respond with an Offer containing IP configuration. The client then sends a Request to accept one offer. Finally, the selected server sends an Acknowledgment confirming the lease.

questions.question: Under which two circumstances would a router usually be configured as a DHCPv4 client? (Choose two.)
options: The administrator needs the router to act as a relay agent.
The router has a fixed IP address.
The router is meant to provide IP addresses to the hosts.
The router is intended to be used as a SOHO gateway.
questions.explanation: A router can be configured as a DHCPv4 client when it needs to obtain its IP address dynamically. This is common in SOHO (Small Office/Home Office) environments where the router connects to an ISP and receives its public IP address via DHCP, or when the router acts as a DHCP relay agent to forward DHCP messages between clients and servers on different subnets.

questions.question: A DHCP-enabled client PC has just booted. During which two steps will the client PC use broadcast messages when communicating with a DHCP server? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: All DHCP messages between a DHCP-enabled client and a DHCP server are using broadcast messages until after the DHCPACK message. The DHCPDISCOVER and DHCPREQUEST messages are the only messages that are sent by a DHCP-enabled client. All DHCP messages between a DHCP-enabled client and a DHCP server use broadcast messages when the client is obtaining a lease for the first time.

questions.question:
An administrator issues the commands:

Router(config)# interface g0/1
Router(config-if)# ip address dhcp

What is the administrator trying to achieve?
options: Configuring the router to obtain IP parameters from a DHCPv4 server
Configuring the router to act as a DHCPv4 server
Configuring the router to resolve IP address conflicts
Configuring the router to act as a relay agent
questions.explanation: The 'ip address dhcp' command activates the DHCPv4 client on a given interface. By doing this, the router will obtain the IP parameters from a DHCPv4 server.

questions.question: When a client is requesting an initial address lease from a DHCP server, why is the DHCPREQUEST message sent as a broadcast?
options: The client does not yet know the IP address of the DHCP server that sent the offer.
The client may have received offers from multiple servers, and the broadcast serves to implicitly decline those other offers.
The client does not have a MAC address assigned yet, so it cannot send a unicast message at Layer 2.
The DHCP server may be on a different subnet, so the request must be sent as a broadcast.
questions.explanation: During the initial DHCP exchange between a client and server, the client broadcasts a DHCPDISCOVER message looking for DHCP servers. Multiple servers may be configured to respond to this request with DHCPOFFER messages. The client will choose the lease from one of the servers by sending a DHCPREQUEST message. It sends this message as a broadcast so that the other DHCP servers that sent offers will know that their offers were declined and the corresponding address can go back into the pool.

questions.question:
Which DHCP IPv4 message contains the following information?

Destination address: 255.255.255.255
Client IPv4 address: 0.0.0.0
Default gateway address: 0.0.0.0
Subnet mask: 0.0.0.0
questions.explanation: A client will first send the DHCPDISCOVER broadcast message to find DHCPv4 servers on the network. This message will have the limited broadcast address, 255.255.255.255, as the destination address. The client IPv4 address, the default gateway address, and subnet fields will all be 0.0.0.0 because these have not yet been configured on the client. When the DHCPv4 server receives a DHCPDISCOVER message, it reserves an available IPv4 address to lease to the client and sends the unicast DHCPOFFER message to the requesting client.

questions.question: What kind of message is sent by a DHCPv4 client requesting an IP address?
questions.explanation: When the DHCPv4 client requests an IP address, it sends a DHCPDISCOVER broadcast message seeking a DHCPv4 server on the network.

questions.question: As a DHCPv4 client lease is about to expire, what is the message that the client sends the DHCP server?
questions.explanation: When a DHCP client lease is about to expire, the client sends a DHCPREQUEST message to the DHCPv4 server that originally provided the IPv4 address. This allows the client to request that the lease be extended.

questions.question: What is the destination IP address when an IPv4 host sends a DHCPDISCOVER message?
questions.explanation: Because a DHCP client does not have a valid IPv4 address, it must use a broadcast IP address of 255.255.255.255 as the destination address to communicate with the DHCP server. The DHCPDISCOVER message sent by the client is the first message sent in order to make initial contact with a DHCP server.

questions.question: What is the most likely scenario in which the WAN interface of a router would be configured as a DHCP client to be assigned a dynamic IP address from an ISP?
options: The router is also the gateway for a LAN.
There is a web server for public access on the LAN that is attached to the router.
The router is configured as a DHCP server.
It is a SOHO or home broadband router.
questions.explanation: SOHO and home broadband routers are typically set to acquire an IPv4 address automatically from the ISP. The IP address that is assigned is typically a dynamic address to reduce the cost, but a static IP address is possible with more cost. However, if the router is assigned a dynamic IP address, DNS issues will result in the web server behind the router not being easily accessible to the public.

questions.question: Which is a DHCPv4 address allocation method that assigns IPv4 addresses for a limited lease period?
questions.explanation: Dynamic allocation is the most commonly implemented allocation mechanism. It leases the IP parameters for a predefined period of time.

questions.question: What is the reason why the DHCPREQUEST message is sent as a broadcast during the DHCPv4 process?
options: For routers to fill their routing tables with this new information
To notify other DHCP servers on the subnet that the IP address was leased
For hosts on other subnets to receive the information
To notify other hosts not to request the same IP address
questions.explanation: The DHCPREQUEST message is broadcast to inform other DHCP servers that an IP address has been leased.

questions.question: How is a DHCPDISCOVER transmitted on a network to reach a DHCP server?
options: A DHCPDISCOVER message is sent with a multicast IP address that all DHCP servers listen to as the destination address.
A DHCPDISCOVER message is sent with the IP address of the default gateway as the destination address.
A DHCPDISCOVER message is sent with the IP address of the DHCP server as the destination address.
A DHCPDISCOVER message is sent with the broadcast IP address as the destination address.
questions.explanation: The DHCPDISCOVER message is sent by a DHCPv4 client and targets a broadcast IP along with the destination port 67. The DHCPv4 server or servers respond to the DHCPv4 clients by targeting port 68.

questions.question: Which destination IPv4 address does a DHCPv4 client use to send the initial DHCP Discover packet when the client is looking for a DHCP server?
options: The IP address of the default gateway
questions.explanation: Broadcast communications on a network may be directed or limited. A directed broadcast is sent to all hosts on a specific network. A limited broadcast is sent to 255.255.255.255. When a DHCP client needs to send a DHCP Discover packet in order to seek DHCP servers, the client will use this IP address of 255.255.255.255 as the destination in the IP header because it has no knowledge of the IP addresses of DHCP servers.

questions.question: Which address does a DHCPv4 server target when sending a DHCPOFFER message to a client that makes an address request?
questions.explanation: When a DHCPv4 client does not have an IPv4 address, a DHCPv4 server will send a DHCPOFFER message back to the client hardware address of the requesting DHCPv4 client.

questions.question: What is the result of a network technician issuing the command ip dhcp excluded-address 10.0.15.1 10.0.15.15 on a Cisco router?
options: The Cisco router will automatically create a DHCP pool using a /28 mask.
The Cisco router will exclude only the 10.0.15.1 and 10.0.15.15 IP addresses from being leased to DHCP clients.
The Cisco router will exclude 15 IP addresses from being leased to DHCP clients.
The Cisco router will allow only the specified IP addresses to be leased to clients.
questions.explanation: The 'ip dhcp excluded-address' command is followed by the first and the last addresses to be excluded from being leased to DHCP clients. In this case, addresses 10.0.15.1 through 10.0.15.15 (15 addresses total) will be excluded.

questions.question: Which message does an IPv4 host use to reply when it receives a DHCPOFFER message from a DHCP server?
questions.explanation: When the client receives the DHCPOFFER from the server, it sends back a DHCPREQUEST broadcast message. On receiving the DHCPREQUEST message, the server replies with a unicast DHCPACK message.

questions.question: A client device on an Ethernet segment needs an IP address in order to communicate on the network. A DHCP server with IP address 192.168.1.1 has been configured and enabled on the network. How will a client device obtain a usable IP address for this network?
options: Send a DHCPREQUEST packet to IP address 255.255.255.255.
Use a statically configured IP address from the pool of IP addresses that is offered by the DHCP server.
Send a DHCPACK packet to the default gateway address.
Send a DHCPDISCOVER message to physical address FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF.
questions.explanation: Like IP addressing, there is also a special MAC address for broadcast purposes: FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF. When a DHCP client needs to send a DHCP Discover message in order to seek DHCP servers, the client will use this MAC address as the destination MAC address in the Ethernet frame. It does this because it has no knowledge of the IP and MAC addresses of DHCP servers.

questions.question: Which statement is true about DHCP operation?
options: The DHCPDISCOVER message contains the IP address and subnet mask to be assigned, the IP address of the DNS server, and the IP address of the default gateway.
When a device that is configured to use DHCP boots, the client broadcasts a DHCPDISCOVER message to identify any available DHCP servers on the network.
A client must wait for lease expiration before it sends another DHCPREQUEST message.
If the client receives several DHCPOFFER messages from different servers, it sends a unicast DHCPREQUEST message to the server from which it chooses to obtain the IP information.
questions.explanation: The client broadcasts a DHCPDISCOVER message to identify any available DHCP servers on the network. A DHCP server replies with a DHCPOFFER message. This message offers to the client a lease that contains such information as the IP address and subnet mask to be assigned, the IP address of the DNS server, and the IP address of the default gateway. After the client receives the lease, the received information must be renewed through another DHCPREQUEST message prior to the lease expiration.

questions.question: Which command, when issued in the interface configuration mode of a router, enables the interface to acquire an IPv4 address automatically from an ISP, when that link to the ISP is enabled?
questions.explanation: The 'ip address dhcp' interface configuration command configures an Ethernet interface as a DHCP client. The 'service dhcp' global configuration command enables the DHCPv4 server process on the router. The 'ip helper-address' command is issued to enable DHCP relay on the router. The 'ip dhcp pool' command creates the name of a pool of addresses that the server can assign to hosts.

questions.question: What information can be verified through the show ip dhcp binding command?
options: that DHCPv4 discover messages are still being received by the DHCP server
the number of IP addresses remaining in the DHCP pool
the IPv4 addresses that have been excluded from the DHCPv4 pool
the IPv4 addresses that are assigned to hosts by the DHCP server
questions.explanation: The 'show ip dhcp binding' command shows a list of IPv4 addresses and the MAC addresses of the hosts to which they are assigned. Using this information an administrator can determine which host interfaces have been assigned to specific hosts.

questions.question: Which protocol automates assignment of IP addresses on a network, and which port number does it use? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: DNS uses port 53 and translates URLs to IP addresses. SMB provides shared access to files and printers and uses port 445. Port 80 is used by HTTP. HTTP is a protocol used to communicate between a web browser and a server. DHCP automates IP address assignment and uses port 67 (server) and port 68 (client).

questions.question: A company uses DHCP servers to dynamically assign IPv4 addresses to employee workstations. The address lease duration is set as 5 days. An employee returns to the office after an absence of one week. When the employee boots the workstation, it sends a message to obtain an IP address. Which Layer 2 and Layer 3 destination addresses will the message contain?
options: FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF and IPv4 address of the DHCP server
MAC address of the DHCP server and 255.255.255.255
both MAC and IPv4 addresses of the DHCP server
questions.explanation: When the lease of a dynamically assigned IPv4 address has expired, a workstation will send a DHCPDISCOVER message to start the process of obtaining a valid IP address. Because the workstation does not know the addresses of DHCP servers, it sends the message via broadcast, with destination addresses of FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF and 255.255.255.255.

questions.question: What is a result when the DHCP servers are not operational in a network?
options: Workstations are assigned with IP addresses in the 169.254.0.0/16 network.
Workstations are assigned with the IP address 127.0.0.1.
Workstations are assigned with IP addresses in the 10.0.0.0/8 network.
Workstations are assigned with the IP address 0.0.0.0.
questions.explanation: When workstations are configured with obtaining IP address automatically but DHCP servers are not available to respond to the requests, a workstation can assign itself an IP addresses from the 169.254.0.0/16 network. This is called Automatic Private IP Addressing (APIPA).

questions.question: What is the reason that an ISP commonly assigns a DHCP address to a wireless router in a SOHO environment?
questions.explanation: In a SOHO environment, a wireless router connects to the ISP via a DSL or cable modem. The IP address between the wireless router and ISP site is typically assigned by the ISP through DHCP. This method facilitates the IP addressing management in that IP addresses for clients are dynamically assigned so that if a client is dropped, the assigned IP address can be easily reassigned to another client.

questions.question: A host PC is attempting to lease an address through DHCP. What message is sent by the server to let the client know it is able to use the provided IP information?
questions.explanation: When a host uses DHCP to automatically configure an IP address, the typically sends two messages: the DHCPDISCOVER message and the DHCPREQUEST message. These two messages are usually sent as broadcasts to ensure that all DHCP servers receive them. The servers respond to these messages using DHCPOFFER, DHCPACK, and DHCPNACK messages, depending on the circumstance. The DHCPACK message confirms that the client can use the provided IP information.

questions.question: Which command will allow a network administrator to check the IP address that is assigned to a particular MAC address?
options: Router# show ip dhcp server statistics
questions.explanation: The 'show ip dhcp binding' command will show the leases, including IP addresses, MAC addresses, lease expiration, type of lease, client ID, and user name.

questions.question: Which set of commands will configure a router as a DHCP server that will assign IPv4 addresses to the 192.168.100.0/23 LAN while reserving the first 10 and the last addresses for static assignment?
options:
dhcp pool LAN-POOL-100
ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.100.1 192.168.100.9
ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.100.254
network 192.168.100.0 255.255.254.0
default-router 192.168.101.1

ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.100.1 192.168.100.10
ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.100.254
ip dhcp pool LAN-POOL-100
network 192.168.100.0 255.255.255.0
ip default-gateway 192.168.100.1

ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.100.1 192.168.100.10
ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.101.254
ip dhcp pool LAN-POOL-100
network 192.168.100.0 255.255.254.0
default-router 192.168.100.1

ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.100.1 192.168.100.9
ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.101.254
ip dhcp pool LAN-POOL-100
ip network 192.168.100.0 255.255.254.0
ip default-gateway 192.168.100.1
questions.explanation: The /23 prefix is equivalent to a network mask of 255.255.254.0. The network usable IPv4 address range is 192.168.100.1 to 192.168.101.254 inclusive. The commands 'dhcp pool', 'ip default-gateway', and 'ip network' are not valid DHCP configuration commands.

questions.question: A small coffee shop is offering free Wi-Fi to customers. The network includes a wireless router and a DSL modem that is connected to the local phone company. What method is typically used to configure the connection to the phone company?
options: Set the WAN connection in the wireless router as a DHCP client.
Set the DSL modem as a DHCP client to get a public IP address from the wireless router.
Set the connection between the wireless router and the DSL modem as a private IP network.
Set the DSL modem as a DHCP client to the phone company and a DHCP server for the internal connection.
questions.explanation: In a SOHO environment, a wireless router connects to an ISP via a DSL or cable modem. The IP address between the wireless router and ISP site is typically assigned by the ISP through DHCP. The DSL modem does not manage IP address allocation.

questions.question: The address pool of a DHCP server is configured with 10.92.71.0/25. The network administrator reserves 8 IP addresses for servers. How many IP addresses are left in the pool to be assigned to other hosts?
questions.explanation: Calculate the maximum number of hosts available for the slash value and subtract the required static IP addresses required for the devices. /24 = 254 hosts, /25 = 126 hosts, /26 = 62 hosts, /27 = 30 hosts, /28 = 14 hosts. For /25, there are 126 usable hosts. Subtracting 8 reserved addresses leaves 118 addresses available for DHCP.

When a Windows computer cannot communicate with an IPv4 DHCP server, the computer automatically assigns itself an IP address in the169.254.0.0/16 range. Linux and Apple computers do not automatically assign an IP address.
questions.question: Which process failed if a computer cannot access the internet and received an IP address of 169.254.142.5?

questions.explanation: Voice and video traffic have delay sensitive characteristics and must be given priority over other traffic types such as web, email, and file transfer traffic. This ensures that quality is maintained for real-time communications.
questions.question: Which two traffic types require delay sensitive delivery? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: The correct command to configure a switch port as an access port assigned to VLAN 10 is 'switchport access vlan 10'. However, to fully configure the port, you must also use 'switchport mode access' to ensure the port operates in access mode. The other options contain incorrect syntax or refer to trunk mode, which is not applicable here.
questions.question: Which command configures a switch port as an access port assigned to VLAN 10?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 8

questions.explanation: The native VLAN is used to carry untagged traffic across an 802.1Q trunk. It ensures that any frame received without a VLAN tag is assigned to a specific VLAN for processing, and frames belonging to the native VLAN are sent across the trunk without a tag.
options: To carry all untagged traffic on the trunk
To provide the default gateway for the VLANs
To encrypt all traffic passing through the trunk
To load balance traffic across multiple VLANs
questions.question: What is the purpose of the native VLAN on an 802.1Q trunk link?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 8

questions.explanation:
LACP (Link Aggregation Control Protocol) is the IEEE 802.3ad standard. It allows for the dynamic negotiation of an EtherChannel bundle between switches, even those from different vendors. When configured in active mode, the switch initiates negotiation by sending LACP packets.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • PAgP: While it negotiates, it is Cisco-proprietary, not an IEEE standard.
  • VTP: Used for VLAN database synchronization, not link aggregation.
  • STP: Used to prevent Layer 2 loops; it does not bundle links.
questions.question: Which EtherChannel protocol is an IEEE standard that actively negotiates the formation of an EtherChannel?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 9

questions.explanation: The Learning state in STP allows the switch to populate its MAC address table by learning MAC addresses from frames passing through the port, but it does not forward frames. This prevents temporary loops while the switch builds its MAC address table. The port states in order are: Blocking (no MAC learning, no forwarding), Listening (no MAC learning, no forwarding), Learning (MAC learning, no forwarding), and Forwarding (MAC learning and frame forwarding).
questions.question: In Spanning Tree Protocol (STP), which port state allows the learning of MAC addresses but does NOT forward frames?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 9

questions.explanation: An interface status of 'up/down' means the physical layer (Layer 1) is up and functioning, but the data link layer (Layer 2) is down. This could be caused by issues such as mismatched encapsulation, a Layer 2 protocol not being established, or configuration problems. 'Administratively down' would show as 'administratively down/down', a disconnected cable would typically show 'down/down', and proper functioning would show 'up/up'.
options: The physical layer is functioning but there is a data link layer problem
Both the physical and data link layers are functioning properly
questions.question: A network administrator notices that a switch interface shows a status of 'up/down'. What does this typically indicate?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 4

questions.explanation: The Root Bridge in STP is determined by the Bridge ID, which consists of the Bridge Priority and the MAC address. The switch with the lowest Bridge ID becomes the Root Bridge. The comparison is made first on Bridge Priority (default 32768), and if priorities are equal, then on the lowest MAC address. Therefore, lowest Bridge Priority and lowest MAC address are the determining factors. By default, the switch with the lowest MAC address becomes the Root Bridge unless priorities are manually configured.
questions.question: Which two factors determine the Root Bridge in Spanning Tree Protocol? (Choose two)
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 9

questions.explanation: PortFast causes an access port to immediately transition from blocking to forwarding state, bypassing the listening and learning states. This feature should only be enabled on ports connected to end devices (hosts), never on ports connected to switches or hubs, as it could create loops. PortFast significantly reduces the time it takes for a workstation to connect to the network from about 50 seconds to just a few seconds. The command is 'spanning-tree portfast' in interface configuration mode.
options: To speed up convergence on trunk ports
To immediately transition access ports to forwarding state
To enable faster root bridge election
questions.question: What is the purpose of PortFast in Spanning Tree Protocol?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 9

questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) should be used instead of Telnet for secure remote access to network devices. SSH encrypts all traffic including passwords, while Telnet sends everything in clear text. SSH uses TCP port 22 by default. To enable SSH on a Cisco device, you need to configure a hostname, domain name, generate crypto keys, and create user accounts. The command 'transport input ssh' on VTY lines restricts access to SSH only.
questions.question: Which protocol should be used instead of Telnet for secure remote access to network devices?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 7

questions.explanation: In the 2.4 GHz frequency band, channels 1, 6, and 11 are the only channels that do not overlap with each other. This is because each channel is 22 MHz wide, but they are spaced only 5 MHz apart. Channels 1, 6, and 11 are spaced 25 MHz apart, allowing them to operate without interference.
