Using these channels maximizes non-overlapping coverage in wireless network design.
questions.question: In the 2.4 GHz frequency band, which channels do NOT overlap with each other?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 2, Chapter 24

questions.explanation: When a switch receives a frame with an unknown destination MAC address (one not in its MAC address table), it floods the frame out all ports except the port on which it was received. This is called unknown unicast flooding. The switch learns MAC addresses dynamically by examining the source MAC address of incoming frames. ARP is a Layer 3 protocol and is not used by switches for MAC address learning. Switches do not forward frames to the default gateway based on MAC addresses.
options: Forward the frame out all ports except the port it was received on (flood)
Send an ARP request to learn the MAC address
Forward the frame to the default gateway
questions.question: What action does a switch take when it receives a frame with a destination MAC address that is NOT in its MAC address table?
references: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide Vol 1, Chapter 5

questions.explanation: IANA is responsible for global IP address allocation and other internet protocol resources. IEEE develops standards for networking technologies, including Ethernet and Wi-Fi. IETF is responsible for the development and promotion of voluntary internet standards and protocols, particularly the standards that comprise the internet protocol suite (TCP/IP).
questions.question: Which three acronyms/initialisms represent standards organizations? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: Network security includes protecting the confidentiality of data that is on the network. In this case, because confidential data has been made available to unauthorized users, the security characteristic of the network has failed.
questions.question: A networking technician is working on the wireless network at a medical clinic. The technician accidentally sets up the wireless network so that patients can see the medical records data of other patients. Which of the four network characteristics has been violated in this situation?

questions.explanation:
The copy running-config startup-config command saves the active configuration currently in RAM (Volatile) to the NVRAM (Non-Volatile RAM). The file in NVRAM is the "startup-config," which the switch reads during the boot process. By issuing this command, you ensure that your changes persist and are re-applied if the device loses power or is rebooted. Why the other options are incorrect:
  • The new configuration will be stored in flash memory: While some files are stored in flash (like the IOS image or VLAN database), the startup-config is specifically stored in NVRAM.
  • The current IOS file will be replaced: This command only affects the configuration text files; it does not modify the Internetwork Operating System (IOS) binary file.
  • The configuration changes will be removed: This describes the opposite action. To discard changes and restore the original configuration, you would either reboot without saving or issue a copy startup-config running-config command.
options: The new configuration will be stored in flash memory.
The new configuration will be loaded if the switch is restarted.
The current IOS file will be replaced with the newly configured file.
The configuration changes will be removed and the original configuration will be restored.
questions.question: After making configuration changes on a Cisco switch, a network administrator issues a copy running-config startup-config command. What is the result of issuing this command?

questions.explanation: Topic 4.6.0 - Wireless LAN connectivity is not affected by trees or the elevation of the equipment. Because this is a one room office in an isolated area, there will not be a large number of wireless devices or source of interference operating in the immediate vicinity. The use of a microwave oven could result in signal interference.
options: The large number of trees that surround the office
The elevated location where the wireless LAN was installed
The number of wireless devices that are used in the wireless LAN
questions.question: A wireless LAN is being deployed inside the new one room office that is occupied by the park ranger. The office is located at the highest part of the national park. After network testing is complete, the technicians report that the wireless LAN signal is occasionally affected by some type of interference. What is a possible cause of the signal distortion?

questions.explanation: EMI and RFI can distort network signals because of interference from fluorescent lights or electric motors. Attenuation results in deterioration of the network signal as it travels along copper cabling. Wireless devices can experience loss of signals because of excessive distances from a access point, but this is not crosstalk. Crosstalk is the disturbance caused by the electric or magnetic fields of the signal carried an an adjacent wire within the same cable.
options: The distortion of the network signal from fluorescent lighting
The distortion of the transmitted messages from signals carried in adjacent wires
The weakening of the network signal over long cable lengths
The loss of wireless signal over excessive distance from the access point
questions.question: Which characteristic describes crosstalk?

questions.explanation: The IEEE 802 standards include Ethernet (802.3), wireless LANs (802.11), and wireless PANs (802.15), which are essential for network professionals to understand.
questions.question: Which standards organization oversees development of wireless LAN standards?

questions.explanation: Carrier sense multiple access with collision avoidance (CSMA/CA) is used in wireless networking to manage media contention by checking if the channel is clear before transmitting, thus avoiding collisions. CSMA/CD is used in wired networks. Priority ordering and token passing are not applicable methods for wireless media access control.
questions.question: What method is used to manage contention-based access on a wireless network?

questions.explanation: Topic 6.1.0 - The data link layer is responsible for the exchange of frames between nodes over a physical network media. Specifically the data link layer performs two basic services: - It accepts Layer 3 packets and encapsulates them into frames. - It provides media access control and performs error detection. Path determination is a service provided at Layer 3. A Layer 2 switch builds a MAC address table as part of its operation, but path determination is not the service that is provided by the data link layer.
options: It fragments data packets into the MTU size.
It determines the path to forward packets.
It accepts Layer 3 packets and encapsulates them into frames.
It provides media access control and performs error detection.
It monitors the Layer 2 communication by building a MAC address table.
questions.question: What are two services performed by the data link layer of the OSI model? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation:
A Layer 2 Switch uses a MAC address table (also known as a CAM table) to map specific MAC addresses to its physical ports. When a frame enters the switch, the switch examines the destination MAC address and looks it up in its table to determine the exact port to which the frame should be forwarded. This reduces unnecessary traffic and prevents collisions.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Repeater: This is a Layer 1 device that simply regenerates and retimes electrical signals; it does not read any addresses or make forwarding decisions.
  • Hub: This is also a Layer 1 device. It receives a signal on one port and "floods" it out of all other ports. It does not look at MAC addresses or make intelligent forwarding decisions.
  • Router: This is a Layer 3 device. It makes forwarding decisions based on IP addresses (Logical addresses) found in the packet header, not MAC addresses in the frame header.
questions.question: Which network device makes forwarding decisions based on the destination MAC address that is contained in the frame?

questions.explanation: Wireless Internet Service Providers (WISPs) are typically used in rural areas where traditional wired broadband options like DSL or cable are not available. They provide internet access by using a dish or antenna on the subscriber's property to connect wirelessly to a WISP transmitter.
options: An Internet cafe in a city
A farm in a rural area without wired broadband access
Any home with multiple wireless devices
An apartment in a building with cable access to the Internet
questions.question: In which scenario would the use of a WISP be recommended?

questions.explanation: lf a MAC address is found in the MAC address table, then data is sent to the associated switch port. lf the MAC address is not found in the MAC address table, the data is sent to all switch ports that have devices attached to the same network.
questions.question: Which network device has the primary function to send data to a specific destination based on the information found in the MAC address table?

questions.explanation:
A runt frame is an Ethernet frame that is smaller than the minimum required size of 64 bytes and typically has an invalid Frame Check Sequence (FCS). These are usually the result of collisions or malfunctioning network interface cards (NICs). Cisco switches are designed to identify these malformed frames and automatically drop them to prevent unnecessary traffic from consuming bandwidth and to ensure data integrity.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • The frame is returned to the originating network device: Ethernet is a best-effort delivery system at Layer 2; switches do not "return" bad frames to the sender.
  • The frame is broadcast to all other devices: Forwarding a runt frame would propagate errors throughout the network. Switches only forward valid frames (or unknown unicasts/broadcasts).
  • The frame is sent to the default gateway: A default gateway is used for Layer 3 routing between different networks. Runt frames are Layer 2 errors and are discarded long before routing is considered.
options: The frame is returned to the originating network device.
The frame is broadcast to all other devices on the same network.
The frame is sent to the default gateway.
questions.question: What happens to runt frames received by a Cisco Ethernet switch?

questions.explanation: Topic 7.3.0 - A switch builds a MAC address table by inspecting incoming Layer 2 frames and recording the source MAC address found in the frame header. The discovered and recorded MAC address is then associated with the port used to receive the frame.
options: The destination Layer 3 address of incoming packets
The destination Layer 2 address of outgoing frames
The source Layer 3 address of outgoing packets
The source Layer 2 address of incoming frames
questions.question: What addressing information is recorded by a switch to build its MAC address table?

questions.explanation: Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) is caused by devices operating on similar frequencies as wireless networks. Cordless phones and microwaves are common sources of RFI due to their frequency bands.
questions.question: Which two devices commonly affect wireless networks? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: Wired Ethernet networks use CSMA/CD for media access control. IEEE 802.11 wireless networks use CSMA/CA, a similar method. Media access control defines the way data frames get placed an the media. The controlled access method is deterministic, not a contention-based access to networks. Because each device has its own time to use the medium, controlled access networks such as legacy Token Ring do not have collisions.
options: Media access control provides placement of data frames onto the media.
Contention-based access is also known as deterministic.
Data link layer protocols define the rules for access to different media.
Networks with controlled access have reduced performance due to data collisions.
questions.question: What are three ways that media access control is used in networking? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: The cyclic redundancy check (CRC) part of the trailer is used to determine if the frame has been modified during transit. If the integrity of the frame is verified, the frame is forwarded. If the integrity of the frame cannot be verified, then the frame is dropped.
options: source MAC address in the header
destination MAC address in the header
questions.question: When the store-and-forward method of switching is in use, what part of the Ethernet frame is used to perform an error check?

questions.explanation:
The primary advantage of store-and-forward switching is its ability to ensure data integrity. In this method, the switch receives the entire frame and stores it in buffers before forwarding it. While the frame is stored, the switch performs a Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) using the Frame Check Sequence (FCS) trailer. If the CRC reveals that the frame is corrupted or is a runt, the switch drops it, preventing errors from propagating through the network.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • collision detecting: This is a function of the CSMA/CD protocol on shared media (hubs), not a specific advantage of store-and-forward switching.
  • faster frame forwarding: This is actually the main advantage of cut-through switching, which starts forwarding the frame as soon as the destination MAC address is read, without waiting for the rest of the frame.
  • frame forwarding using IPv4 Layer 3 and 4 information: This describes the behavior of a Layer 3 (Multilayer) switch, not a fundamental Layer 2 switching method like store-and-forward.
options: frame forwarding using IPv4 Layer 3 and 4 information
questions.question: Which advantage does the store-and-forward switching method have compared with the cut-through switching method?

questions.explanation:
Auto-MDIX (Automatic Medium-Dependent Interface Crossover) is a feature that allows a switch or router interface to detect the required cable connection type (straight-through or crossover) and configure the connection appropriately.Historically, connecting "like" devices (e.g., switch-to-switch) required a crossover cable, while connecting "unlike" devices (e.g., PC-to-switch) required a straight-through cable. With auto-MDIX enabled, the interface automatically reconfigures its internal transmit and receive pairs to establish a link regardless of which cable type is used.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • It enables a device to automatically configure the duplex settings: This describes Auto-Negotiation, which handles half-duplex vs. full-duplex settings.
  • It enables a device to automatically configure the speed: This is also part of Auto-Negotiation (e.g., 10/100/1000 Mbps), not MDIX.
  • It enables a switch to dynamically select the forwarding method: This would refer to a switch switching between Store-and-Forward and Cut-Through, which is not what MDIX does.
options: It enables a device to automatically configure an interface to use a straight-through or a crossover cable.
It enables a device to automatically configure the duplex settings of a segment.
It enables a device to automatically configure the speed of its interface.
It enables a switch to dynamically select the forwarding method.
questions.question: What is the auto-MDIX feature?

questions.explanation: Fast-forward switching, a type of cut-through switching, begins to forward a frame after reading the destination MAC address, resulting in the lowest latency. Fragment-free reads the first 64 bytes before forwarding. Store-and-forward has the highest latency because it reads the entire frame before forwarding. Both fragment-free and fast-forward are types of cut-through switching, but fast-forward specifically has the lowest latency.
questions.question: Which switching method has the lowest level of latency?

questions.explanation: When the store-and-forward switching method is used, the switch receives the complete frame before forwarding it on to the destination. The cyclic redundancy check (CRC) part of the trailer is used to determine if the frame has been modified during transit. In contrast, a cut-through switch forwards the frame once the destination Layer 2 address is read. Two types of cut-through switching methods are fast-forward and fragment-free.
questions.question: Which switching method uses the CRC value in a frame?

questions.explanation: Cut-through switching provides lower latency because it begins forwarding a frame before the entire frame is received, unlike store-and-forward switching which waits for the entire frame to be received and checked for errors.
options: has a positive impact on bandwidth by dropping most of the invalid frames
makes a fast forwarding decision based on the source MAC address of the frame
has a lower latency appropriate for high-performance computing applications
provides the flexibility to support any mix of Ethernet speeds
questions.question: What is one advantage of using the cut-through switching method instead of the store-and-forward switching method?

questions.explanation: A Layer 2 switch uses its MAC address table to determine how to forward frames. If the destination MAC address is not found in the table, the switch floods the frame out of all ports except the one it was received on, to ensure it reaches its destination.
options: It broadcasts the frame out of all ports on the switch.
It notifies the sending host that the frame cannot be delivered.
It forwards the frame out of all ports except for the port at which the frame was received.
questions.question: What will a Layer 2 switch do when the destination MAC address of a received frame is not in the MAC table?

questions.explanation: When a Layer 2 switch receives a broadcast frame, it forwards the frame to all ports except the one it was received on, effectively flooding the network segment.
options: It sends the frame to all ports except the port on which it received the frame.
It sends the frame to all ports that are registered to forward broadcasts.
It sends the frame to all ports.
questions.question: Which action is taken by a Layer 2 switch when it receives a Layer 2 broadcast frame?

questions.explanation: The MAC address of PC3 is not present in the MAC table of the switch. Because the switch does not know where to send the frame that is addressed to PC3, it will forward the frame to all the switch ports, except for port 4, which is the incoming port.
options: The switch will discard the frame.
The switch will forward the frame only to port 2.
The switch will forward the frame to all ports except port 4.
The switch will forward the frame to all ports.
The switch will forward the frame only to ports 1 and 3.
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. The exhibit shows a small switched network and the contents of the MAC address table of the switch. PC1 has sent a frame addressed to PC3. What will the switch do with the frame?

questions.explanation:
A Layer 2 device, such as an Ethernet switch, makes its primary forwarding decision based on the destination MAC address. When a frame enters a switch port, the switch looks at the destination MAC address in the frame header and consults its MAC address table (or CAM table) to find out which physical port is associated with that specific address.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • source MAC address: The switch examines this address only to learn which device is connected to which port and to update its MAC address table. It does not use the source address to decide where to forward the frame.
  • source IP address & destination IP address: These are Layer 3 (Network Layer) headers. Standard Layer 2 switches do not "look inside" the packet to see IP addresses; they only look at the outer Ethernet frame.
  • ethernet type: This field (also known as the EtherType) tells the receiving device which protocol is encapsulated in the frame (e.g., IPv4 or IPv6), but it is not used to determine the forwarding path.
questions.question: What important information is examined in the Ethernet frame header by a Layer 2 device in order to forward the data onward?

questions.explanation: Large numbers of ARP broadcast messages could cause momentary data communications delays. Network attackers could manipulate MAC address and IP address mappings in ARP messages with the intent to intercept network traffic. ARP requests and replies cause entries to be made into the ARP table, not the MAC address table. ARP table overflows are very unlikely. Manually configuring static ARP associations is a way to prevent, not facilitate, ARP poisoning and MAC address spoofing. Multiple ARP replies resulting in the switch MAC address table containing entries that match the MAC addresses of connected nodes and are associated with the relevant switch port are required for normal switch frame forwarding operations. lt is not an ARP caused network problem.
options: Manually configuring static ARP associations could facilitate ARP poisoning or MAC address spoofing.
On large networks with low bandwidth, multiple ARP broadcasts could cause data communication delays.
Network attackers could manipulate MAC address and IP address mappings in ARP messages with the intent of intercepting network traffic.
Large numbers of ARP request broadcasts could cause the host MAC address table to overflow and prevent the host from communicating on the network.
Multiple ARP replies result in the switch MAC address table containing entries that match the MAC addresses of hosts that are connected to the relevant switch port.
questions.question: What are two potential network problems that can result from ARP operation? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: The MAC address of PC3 is not present in the MAC table of the switch. Because the switch does not know where to send the frame that is addressed to PC3, it will forward the frame to all the switch ports, except for port 4, which is the incoming port.
options: The switch will discard the frame.
The switch will forward the frame only to port 2.
The switch will forward the frame to all ports except port 4.
The switch will forward the frame to all ports.
The switch will forward the frame only to ports 1 and 3.
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. The exhibit shows a small switched network and the contents of the MAC address table of the switch. PC1 has sent a frame addressed to PC3. What will the switch do with the frame?

questions.explanation: Fast-forward switching offers the lowest level of latency and is the typical cut-through method of switching. It starts forwarding before the entire packet is received, which can lead to forwarding packets with errors. Fragment-free switching is a compromise between store-and-forward and fast-forward switching.
options: The fragment-free switching offers the lowest level of latency.
Fast-forward switching can be viewed as a compromise between store-and-forward switching and fragment-free switching.
Fragment-free switching is the typical cut-through method of switching.
Packets can be relayed with errors when fast-forward switching is used.
questions.question: Two network engineers are discussing the methods used to forward frames through a switch. What is an important concept related to the cut-through method of switching?

questions.explanation: When a switch receives a frame with a CRC error, it discards the frame to prevent the propagation of corrupted data. This is a fundamental error-checking mechanism in networking.
options: The switch places the new CRC value in the FCS field and forwards the frame.
The switch notifies the source of the bad frame.
The switch floods the frame to all ports except the port through which the frame arrived to notify the hosts of the error.
The purpose of the CRC value in the FCS field is to determine if the frame has errors. If the frame does have errors, then the frame is dropped by the switch.
questions.question: What happens when a switch receives a frame and the calculated CRC value is different than the value that is in the FCS field?

questions.explanation: Topic 3.1.0 - Before a message is sent across a network it must first be encoded. Encoding is the process of converting the data message into another format suitable for transmission across the physical medium. Each bit of the message is encoded into a pattern of sounds, light waves, or electrical impulses depending on the network media over which the bits are transmitted. The destination host receives and decodes the signals in order to interpret the message.
options: To convert information to the appropriate form for transmission
To break large messages into smaller frames
To negotiate correct timing for successful communication
questions.question: In computer communication, what is the purpose of message encoding?
What happens to a port that is associated with VLAN 10 when the administrator deletes VLAN 10 from the switch?
options: The port goes back to the default VLAN.
The port automatically associates itself with the native VLAN.
The port creates the VLAN again.
questions.explanation: If the VLAN that is associated with a port is deleted, the port becomes inactive and cannot communicate with the network any more. The port does not automatically move to another VLAN. To verify that a port is in an inactive state, use the show interfaces switchport command.

questions.question: In which memory location are the VLAN configurations of normal range VLANs stored on a Catalyst switch?
questions.explanation: When a normal range VLAN is created the configuration information of the VLAN is stored in flash in the vlan.dat file. This file persists across reboots. NVRAM stores the startup-config, RAM stores the running-config, and ROM stores the bootstrap and POST routines.

questions.question: An administrator is investigating a failure on a trunk link between a Cisco switch and a switch from another vendor. After a few show commands, the administrator notices that the switches are not negotiating a trunk. What is a probable cause for this issue?
options: Both switches are in trunk mode.
Both switches are in nonegotiate mode.
Switches from other vendors do not support DTP.
DTP frames are flooding the entire network.
questions.explanation: DTP (Dynamic Trunking Protocol) is a Cisco proprietary protocol. Non-Cisco switches do not support DTP. When connecting to non-Cisco switches, you should manually configure the trunk using the switchport mode trunk and switchport nonegotiate commands.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the vlan.dat file on a switch?
questions.explanation: The VLAN database (vlan.dat) contains information about normal range VLANs such as the VLAN number, name, and VTP mode. This file is stored in flash memory and is separate from the startup-config file stored in NVRAM.

questions.question: What is the purpose of setting the native VLAN separate from data VLANs?
options: The native VLAN is for carrying VLAN management traffic only.
The security of management frames that are carried in the native VLAN can be enhanced.
A separate VLAN should be used to carry uncommon untagged frames to avoid bandwidth contention on data VLANs.
The native VLAN is for routers and switches to exchange their management information, so it should be different from data VLANs.
questions.explanation: When a Cisco switch trunk port receives untagged frames (unusual in well-designed networks), it forwards these frames to the native VLAN. When the native VLAN is moved away from data VLANs, those untagged frames will not compete for bandwidth in the data VLANs. The native VLAN is not designed for carrying management traffic, but rather it is for backward compatibility with legacy LAN scenarios.

questions.question: When a Cisco switch receives untagged frames on a 802.1Q trunk port, which VLAN ID is the traffic switched to by default?
questions.explanation: A native VLAN is used to forward untagged frames that are received on a Cisco switch 802.1Q trunk port. Untagged frames that are received on a trunk port are not forwarded to any other VLAN except the native VLAN. By default, the native VLAN is VLAN 1.

questions.question: A network administrator is determining the best placement of VLAN trunk links. Which two types of point-to-point connections utilize VLAN trunking? (Choose two.)
options: Between two switches that utilize multiple VLANs
Between a switch and a client PC
Between a switch and a server that has an 802.1Q NIC
Between a switch and a network printer
Between two switches that share a common VLAN
questions.explanation: VLAN trunk links are used to allow all VLAN traffic to propagate between devices such as the link between a switch and a server that has an 802.1Q-capable NIC. Switches can also utilize trunk links to routers, servers, and to other switches when multiple VLANs need to traverse the link.

questions.question: What are three primary benefits of using VLANs? (Choose three.)
options: A reduction in the number of trunk links
questions.explanation: Security, cost reduction, and improved IT staff efficiency are all benefits of using VLANs, along with higher performance, broadcast storm mitigation, and simpler project and application management. End users are not usually aware of VLANs, and VLANs do require configuration. Because VLANs are assigned to access ports, they do not reduce the number of trunk links.
Decoding is the process of converting encoded data back into its original format so that it can be understood. This is a fundamental step in data communication.
questions.question: What process is used to receive transmitted data and convert it into a readable message?
On a Cisco switch, where is extended range VLAN information stored?
questions.explanation: Extended range VLANs, 1006 through 4094, are not written to the vlan.dat file but are saved in the running configuration file. To persist extended range VLANs across reboots, you must save the running-config to startup-config.

questions.question: In which location are the normal range VLANs stored on a Cisco switch by default?
questions.explanation: Normal range VLANs (1-1005) are stored in a file called vlan.dat and located in the flash memory. This file is automatically maintained and persists across reboots without needing to save the running-config.

questions.question: Which distinct type of VLAN is used by an administrator to access and configure a switch?
questions.explanation: A management VLAN is used to remotely access and configure a switch. Data VLANs are used to separate a network into groups of users or devices. The default VLAN is the initial VLAN all switch ports are placed in when loading the default configuration on a switch. The 802.1Q trunk port places untagged traffic on the native VLAN.

questions.question: For what reason would a network administrator use the show interfaces trunk command on a switch?
options: To examine DTP negotiation as it occurs
To verify port association with a particular VLAN
To display an IP address for any existing VLAN
questions.explanation: The show interfaces trunk command displays the ports that are trunk ports, the trunking mode, the encapsulation type, the trunk status, the native VLAN, and the allowed VLANs on the link. It does not show DTP negotiation in real-time.

questions.question: Where is the vlan.dat file stored on a switch?
options: On the externally attached storage media or internal hard drive
questions.explanation: Normal range VLAN configurations are stored within a VLAN database file, called vlan.dat, which is located in the flash memory of the switch. This file persists across reboots and is separate from the startup-config.

questions.question: If an organization is changing to include Cisco IP phones in its network, what design feature must be considered to ensure voice quality?
options: Voice traffic needs to be tagged with the native VLAN.
A separate VLAN is needed for voice traffic.
Additional switch ports that are dedicated to Cisco IP phones are required.
Voice traffic and data traffic require separate trunk links between switches.
questions.explanation: A PC commonly connects to an IP phone and the IP phone, in turn, connects to a switch. The phone does not require a separate port. Because voice traffic cannot tolerate much packet delay, it needs to be in a separate VLAN. The voice VLAN can be configured to provide quality of service (QoS), which will ensure that the voice traffic has a higher priority than data traffic.

questions.question: A Cisco switch currently allows traffic tagged with VLANs 10 and 20 across trunk port Fa0/5. What is the effect of issuing a switchport trunk allowed vlan 30 command on Fa0/5?
options: It allows VLANs 1 to 30 on Fa0/5.
It allows VLANs 10, 20, and 30 on Fa0/5.
It allows only VLAN 30 on Fa0/5.
It allows a native VLAN of 30 to be implemented on Fa0/5.
questions.explanation: The switchport trunk allowed vlan 30 command replaces the allowed VLAN list with only VLAN 30. Any VLAN that is not specified in this command will not be allowed on this trunk port. To add VLAN 30 while keeping existing VLANs, use 'switchport trunk allowed vlan add 30' instead.

A switch, as a Layer 2 device, does not need an IP address to transmit frames to attached devices. However, when a switch is accessed remotely through the network, it must have a Layer 3 address. The IP address must be applied to a virtual interface rather than to a physical interface. Routers, not switches, function as default gateways.
options: to enable the switch to send broadcast frames to attached PCs
to enable the switch to function as a default gateway
to enable the switch to be managed remotely
to enable the switch to receive frames from attached PCs
questions.question: Why would a Layer 2 switch need an IP address?
Which type of VLAN is used to designate which traffic is untagged when crossing a trunk port?
questions.explanation: A native VLAN is the VLAN that does not receive a VLAN tag in the IEEE 802.1Q frame header. Cisco best practices recommend the use of an unused VLAN (not a data VLAN, the default VLAN of VLAN 1, or the management VLAN) as the native VLAN whenever possible for security reasons.

questions.question: A network administrator issues the show vlan brief command while troubleshooting a user support ticket. What output will be displayed?
options: the VLAN assignment and membership for device MAC addresses
the VLAN assignment and membership for all switch ports
the VLAN assignment and trunking encapsulation
the VLAN assignment and native VLAN
questions.explanation: The show vlan brief command will provide information displaying the VLAN assignment and membership for all switch ports on a switch. It shows VLAN IDs, names, status, and which ports are assigned to each VLAN.

questions.question: PC1 in VLAN 10 (192.168.10.0/24) is unable to communicate with Server 1 in VLAN 20 (192.168.20.0/24). The network has switches ALS1, DLS1, and ALS2 connected in series. The show interfaces trunk command on DLS1 shows only Gig0/1 as a trunk port. What conclusion can be made?
options: Interface G0/2 is not configured as a trunk.
The encapsulation on interface G0/1 is incorrect.
The DTP mode is incorrectly set to dynamic auto on interface G0/1.
questions.explanation: In the show interfaces trunk output, if the G0/2 interface of DLS1 is not listed, this indicates the interface has probably not been configured as a trunk link. For inter-VLAN traffic to flow between switches, all intermediate links must be configured as trunks to carry VLAN-tagged traffic.

questions.question: Which two characteristics describe the native VLAN? (Choose two.)
options: Designed to carry traffic that is generated by users, this type of VLAN is also known as the default VLAN.
The native VLAN traffic will be untagged across the trunk link.
This VLAN is necessary for remote management of a switch.
High priority traffic, such as voice traffic, uses the native VLAN.
The native VLAN provides a common identifier to both ends of a trunk.
questions.explanation: The native VLAN is assigned to 802.1Q trunks to provide a common identifier to both ends of the trunk link. Whatever VLAN native number is assigned to a port, or if the port is the default VLAN of 1, the port does not tag any frame in that VLAN as the traffic travels across the trunk. The native VLAN should be an unused VLAN that is distinct from VLAN 1, the default VLAN, as well as other VLANs.

questions.question: Which command displays the encapsulation type, the voice VLAN ID, and the access mode VLAN for the Fa0/1 interface?
questions.explanation: The show interfaces switchport command displays the following information for a given port: Switchport status, Administrative Mode, Operational Mode, Administrative Trunking Encapsulation, Operational Trunking Encapsulation, Negotiation of Trunking, Access Mode VLAN, Trunking Native Mode VLAN, Administrative Native VLAN tagging, and Voice VLAN.

Topic 4.6.0 - When the end-user devices need mobility to connect to the network, wireless is recommended. If an end-user device only has an Ethernet NIC, the user will only be able to use Ethernet cabling. If RFI is an issue, wireless is not recommended. An end-user device that requires a dedicated connection for performance would perform better with a dedicated Ethernet cable.
options: The end-user device only has an Ethernet NIC.
The end-user device requires a dedicated connection because of performance requirements.
The end-user device needs mobility when connecting to the network.
The end-user device area has a high concentration of RFI.
questions.question: A network administrator is designing a new network infrastructure that includes both wired and wireless connectivity. Under which situation would a wireless connection be recommended?
What happens to switch ports after the VLAN to which they are assigned is deleted?
options: The ports are placed in trunk mode.
The ports are assigned to VLAN1, the default VLAN.
The ports stop communicating with the attached devices.
questions.explanation: When a VLAN is deleted from a switch, any ports assigned to that VLAN become inactive and stop communicating with attached devices. The affected ports must be reconfigured for an active VLAN. The ports are not automatically moved to VLAN 1 or trunk mode - they simply become unusable until reassigned.

questions.question: On a switch that is configured with multiple VLANs, which command will remove only VLAN 100 from the switch?
options: Switch(config-if)# no switchport trunk allowed vlan 100
questions.explanation: To remove all VLANs from a switch, the delete flash:vlan.dat command would be used. To change the assigned VLAN for an interface, the 'no switchport access vlan 100' interface configuration command would be used. To remove VLAN 100 as an allowed VLAN on a trunk, the 'no switchport trunk allowed vlan 100' would be used, but this would not remove the VLAN from the switch. To delete a single VLAN, use the 'no vlan 100' global configuration command.

questions.question: A network administrator is reviewing port and VLAN assignments on switch S2 using show vlan brief and notices that interfaces Gi0/1 and Gi0/2 are not included in the output. Why would the interfaces be missing from the output?
options: There is a native VLAN mismatch between the switches.
There is no media connected to the interfaces.
They are configured as trunk interfaces.
questions.explanation: Interfaces that are configured as trunks do not belong to a single VLAN and therefore will not show in the output of the show vlan brief command. Trunk ports carry traffic for multiple VLANs, so they are listed in the show interfaces trunk output instead.

questions.question: Refer to the exhibit showing a Layer 3 switch connected to three Layer 2 access switches with multiple links. Which switching technology would allow each access layer switch link to be aggregated to provide more bandwidth between each Layer 2 switch and the Layer 3 switch?
questions.explanation: PortFast is used to reduce the amount of time that a port spends going through the spanning-tree algorithm, so that devices can start sending data sooner. Trunking can be implemented in conjunction with EtherChannel, but trunking alone does not aggregate switch links. HSRP is used to load-balance traffic across two different connections to Layer 3 devices for default gateway redundancy. HSRP does not aggregate links at either Layer 2 or Layer 3 as EtherChannel does.

questions.question: An administrator wants to form an EtherChannel between two switches by using the Port Aggregation Protocol. If switch S1 is configured to be in auto mode, which mode should be configured on S2 to form the EtherChannel?
questions.explanation: An EtherChannel will be formed via PAgP when both switches are in on mode or when one of them is in auto or desirable mode and the other is in desirable mode. If both sides are in auto mode, the EtherChannel will not form because neither side will initiate the negotiation.

questions.question: In an RSTP-enabled network with S1 as the root bridge, S2 and S3 as access switches connected to S1, what are the possible port roles for ports A (S3 to S2), B (S3 to S1), C (S1 to S2), and D (S3 to S1)?
questions.explanation: Because S1 is the root bridge, B is a designated port, and C and D are root ports (ports leading to the root bridge). RSTP supports a new port type called alternate port in discarding state, which can be port A in this scenario since it provides an alternate path to the root bridge.

questions.question: What is the outcome of a Layer 2 broadcast storm?
options: Routers will take over the forwarding of frames as switches become congested.
New traffic is discarded by the switch because it is unable to be processed.
CSMA/CD will cause each host to continue transmitting frames.
ARP broadcast requests are returned to the transmitting host.
questions.explanation: When the network is saturated with broadcast traffic that is looping between switches, new traffic is discarded by each switch because it is unable to be processed. The switches become overwhelmed trying to forward the looping broadcast frames, leaving no resources for legitimate traffic.

questions.question: A set of switches is being connected in a LAN topology. Which STP bridge priority value will make it least likely for the switch to be selected as the root?
questions.explanation: The STP bridge priority is a two byte number, but it can only be customized in increments of 4096. The smaller the number, the more preferred the switch is for root bridge election. The largest usable priority value is 61440. A switch with priority 61440 is least likely to become root compared to switches with lower priority values like 4096 or 32768.

questions.question: What is a characteristic of spanning tree?
options: It is enabled by default on Cisco switches.
It has a TTL mechanism that works at Layer 2.
It prevents propagation of Layer 2 broadcast frames.
It is used to discover information about an adjacent Cisco device.
questions.explanation: Spanning tree does work at Layer 2 on Ethernet-based networks and is enabled by default, but it does not have a TTL mechanism. Spanning tree exists because Layer 2 frames do not have a TTL mechanism. Layer 2 frames are still broadcast when spanning tree is enabled, but the frames can only be transmitted through a single path through the Layer 2 network that was created by spanning tree. Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) is used to discover information about an adjacent Cisco device.

questions.question: What is the function of STP in a scalable network?
options: It decreases the size of the failure domain to contain the impact of failures.
It protects the edge of the enterprise network from malicious activity.
It disables redundant paths to eliminate Layer 2 loops.
It combines multiple switch trunk links to act as one logical link for increased bandwidth.
questions.explanation: STP is an important component in a scalable network because it allows redundant physical connections between Layer 2 devices to be implemented without creating Layer 2 loops. STP prevents Layer 2 loops from forming by disabling interfaces on Layer 2 devices when they would create a loop.

questions.question: What is the value used to determine which port on a non-root bridge will become a root port in a STP network?
options: the highest MAC address of all the ports in the switch
the lowest MAC address of all the ports in the switch
questions.explanation: STP establishes one root port on each non-root bridge. The root port is the lowest-cost path from the non-root bridge to the root bridge, indicating the direction of the best path to the root bridge. This is primarily based on the path cost to the root bridge.

questions.question: In which two PVST+ port states are MAC addresses learned? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: The two PVST+ port states during which MAC addresses are learned and populate the MAC address table are the learning and the forwarding states. In the blocking, listening, and disabled states, the switch does not learn MAC addresses.

questions.question: If no bridge priority is configured in PVST, which criteria is considered when electing the root bridge?
questions.explanation: Only one switch can be the root bridge for a VLAN. The root bridge is the switch with the lowest BID. The BID is determined by priority and the MAC address. If no priority is configured then all switches use the default priority and the election of the root bridge will be based on the lowest MAC address.

questions.question: In which two port states does a switch learn MAC addresses and process BPDUs in a PVST network? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: Switches learn MAC addresses at the learning and forwarding port states. They receive and process BPDUs at the blocking, listening, learning, and forwarding port states. Only in the forwarding and learning states are MAC addresses added to the MAC address table.

questions.question: Which two network design features require Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) to ensure correct network operation? (Choose two.)
options: link-state dynamic routing that provides redundant routes
removing single points of failure with multiple Layer 2 switches
questions.explanation: Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) is required to ensure correct network operation when designing a network with multiple interconnected Layer 2 switches or using redundant links to eliminate single points of failure between Layer 2 switches. Routing is a Layer 3 function and does not relate to STP. VLANs do reduce the number of broadcast domains but relate to Layer 3 subnets, not STP.

questions.question: When the show spanning-tree vlan 33 command is issued on a switch, three ports are shown in the forwarding state. In which two port roles could these interfaces function while in the forwarding state? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: The role of each of the three ports will be either designated port or root port. Ports in the disabled state are administratively disabled. Ports in the blocking state are alternate ports. Only designated and root ports can be in the forwarding state.

questions.question:
Four switches are connected with the following Bridge IDs:
- S1: Priority 32769, MAC 000A00032222
- S2: Priority 32769, MAC 000A00031111
- S3: Priority 32769, MAC 000A00033333
- S4: Priority 32769, MAC 000A00031212

Which switch will be the root bridge after the election process is complete?
questions.explanation: The root bridge is determined by the lowest bridge ID, which consists of the priority value and the MAC address. Because the priority values of all of the switches are identical (32769), the MAC address is used to determine the root bridge. Because S2 has the lowest MAC address (000A00031111), S2 becomes the root bridge.

questions.question: A network administrator is configuring an EtherChannel link between two switches, SW1 and SW2. SW1 shows 'channel-group 1 mode auto' and SW2 shows 'channel-group 1 mode active'. However, the EtherChannel link fails to establish. What change in configuration would correct the problem?
options: Configure SW1 EtherChannel mode to on.
Configure SW2 EtherChannel mode to on.
Configure SW2 EtherChannel mode to auto.
Configure SW2 EtherChannel mode to desirable.
questions.explanation: The EtherChannel mode must be compatible on each side for the link to work. SW1 uses PAgP mode 'auto', but SW2 uses LACP mode 'active'. These protocols are incompatible. The three modes from PAgP protocol are on, desirable, and auto. The compatible PAgP combinations include on-on, auto-desirable, desirable-desirable, and active-active. Changing SW2 to 'desirable' (PAgP) will allow the EtherChannel to form with SW1's 'auto' mode.

questions.question:
The show etherchannel summary command shows:
Group Port-channel Protocol Ports
1 Po1(SU) PAgP Fa0/1(P) Fa0/2(P)

On the basis of the output that is shown, what can be determined about the EtherChannel bundle?
options: The EtherChannel bundle is operating at both Layer 2 and Layer 3.
Two Gigabit Ethernet ports are used to form the EtherChannel.
A Cisco proprietary protocol was used to negotiate the EtherChannel link.
questions.explanation: Two protocols can be used to send negotiation frames that are used to try to establish an EtherChannel link: PAgP and LACP. PAgP is Cisco proprietary, and LACP adheres to the industry standard. The output shows PAgP was used, which is a Cisco proprietary protocol.

questions.question: Which statement describes a characteristic of EtherChannel?
options: It can combine up to a maximum of 4 physical links.
It can bundle mixed types of 100 Mb/s and 1Gb/s Ethernet links.
It consists of multiple parallel links between a switch and a router.
It is made by combining multiple physical links that are seen as one link between two switches.
questions.explanation: An EtherChannel is formed by combining multiple (same type) Ethernet physical links so they are seen and configured as one logical link. It provides an aggregated link between two switches. Currently each EtherChannel can consist of up to eight compatibly configured Ethernet ports, not four. The links must be of the same speed and type.

questions.question: What are two requirements to be able to configure an EtherChannel between two switches? (Choose two.)
options: The interfaces that are involved need to be contiguous on the switch.
All the interfaces need to work at the same speed.
All the interfaces need to be working in the same duplex mode.
All interfaces need to be assigned to different VLANs.
Different allowed ranges of VLANs must exist on each end.
questions.explanation: All interfaces in the EtherChannel bundle must be assigned to the same VLAN or be configured as a trunk. If the allowed range of VLANs is not the same, the interfaces do not form an EtherChannel even when set to auto or desirable mode. The interfaces must also have the same speed and duplex settings. The interfaces do not need to be physically contiguous.

questions.question: A switch is configured to run STP. What term describes a field that has a default value of 32,768 and is the initial deciding factor when electing a root bridge?
questions.explanation: Bridge priority is the initial deciding factor when electing a root bridge. The default bridge priority value is 32,768 and can be modified in increments of 4096. The switch with the lowest bridge priority becomes the root bridge. If priorities are equal, the MAC address is used as a tiebreaker. The Bridge ID consists of the bridge priority plus the MAC address.

questions.question: What are two advantages of EtherChannel? (Choose two.)
options: Configuring the EtherChannel interface provides consistency in the configuration of the physical links.
Load balancing occurs between links configured as different EtherChannels.
EtherChannel uses upgraded physical links to provide increased bandwidth.
Spanning Tree Protocol views the physical links in an EtherChannel as one logical connection.
Spanning Tree Protocol ensures redundancy by transitioning failed interfaces in an EtherChannel to a forwarding state.
questions.explanation: EtherChannel configuration of one logical interface ensures configuration consistency across the physical links in the EtherChannel. The EtherChannel provides increased bandwidth using existing switch ports without requiring any upgrades to the physical interfaces. Load balancing methods are implemented between links that are part of the same EtherChannel. Because EtherChannel views the bundled physical links as one logical connection, spanning tree recalculation is not required if one of the bundled physical links fail. If a physical interface fails, STP cannot transition the failed interface into a forwarding state.

questions.question: When EtherChannel is configured, which mode will force an interface into a port channel without exchanging aggregation protocol packets?
questions.explanation: For both LACP and PAgP, the 'on' mode will force an interface into an EtherChannel without exchanging protocol packets. The 'active' and 'passive' modes are used with LACP, while 'desirable' and 'auto' are used with PAgP - all of these modes exchange negotiation packets.

questions.question: Which two parameters must match on the ports of two switches to create a PAgP EtherChannel between the switches? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: For an EtherChannel to be created, the ports that are concerned on the two switches must match in terms of the speed, duplex, and VLAN information. The PAgP mode must be compatible but not necessarily equal. The port ID and the MAC addresses do not have to match.

questions.question: Which two channel group modes would place an interface in a negotiating state using PAgP? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: There are three modes available when configuring an interface for PAgP: on, desirable, and auto. Only desirable and auto place the interface in a negotiating state. The active and passive states are used to configure LACP and not PAgP.

questions.question:
Refer to the exhibit. An EtherChannel was configured between switches S1 and S2, but the interfaces do not form an EtherChannel. What is the problem?

S1(config)# interface range FastEthernet0/0 - 1
S1(config-if-range)# channel-group 1 mode active
S1(config-if-range)# interface port-channel 1
S1(config-if)# switchport mode trunk
S1(config-if)# switchport trunk allowed vlan 1-5,10

S2(config)# interface range FastEthernet0/0 - 1
S2(config-if-range)# channel-group 1 mode active
S2(config-if-range)# interface port-channel 1
S2(config-if)# switchport mode trunk
S2(config-if)# switchport trunk allowed vlan 1,5,10
options: The interface port-channel number has to be different on each switch.
The switch ports were not configured with speed and duplex mode.
The switch ports have to be configured as access ports with each port having a VLAN assigned.
The EtherChannel was not configured with the same allowed range of VLANs on each interface.
questions.explanation: The guidelines for configuring an EtherChannel link are: 1. Interfaces which form an EtherChannel can be physically discontiguous, and on different modules. 2. Interfaces in an EtherChannel have to operate at the same speed and in the same duplex mode. 3. Interfaces in the EtherChannel must be assigned to the same VLAN, or be configured as a trunk. 4. Interfaces in the EtherChannel have to support the same allowed range of VLANs. In this case, S1 allows VLANs 1-5,10 but S2 allows VLANs 1,5,10 - the ranges do not match.

questions.question: What is a requirement to configure a trunking EtherChannel between two switches?
options: The participating interfaces must be physically contiguous on a switch.
The allowed range of VLANs must be the same on both switches.
The participating interfaces must be on the same module on a switch.
The participating interfaces must be assigned the same VLAN number on both switches.
questions.explanation: To enable a trunking EtherChannel successfully, the range of VLANs allowed on all the interfaces must match; otherwise, the EtherChannel cannot be formed. The interfaces involved in an EtherChannel do not have to be physically contiguous, or on the same module. Because the EtherChannel is a trunking one, participating interfaces are configured as trunk mode, not access mode.

questions.question: A network administrator configured an EtherChannel link with three interfaces between two switches. What is the result if one of the three interfaces is down?
options: The remaining two interfaces continue to load balance traffic.
The remaining two interfaces become separate links between the two switches.
One interface becomes an active link for data traffic and the other becomes a backup link.
questions.explanation: EtherChannel creates an aggregation that is seen as one logical link. It provides redundancy because the overall link is one logical connection. The loss of one physical link within the channel does not create a change in the topology; the EtherChannel remains functional.

questions.question: Which technology is an open protocol standard that allows switches to automatically bundle physical ports into a single logical link?
questions.explanation: LACP, or Link Aggregation Control Protocol, is defined by IEEE 802.3ad and is an open standard protocol. LACP allows switches to automatically bundle switch ports into a single logical link to increase bandwidth. PAgP, or Port Aggregation Protocol, performs a similar function, but it is a Cisco proprietary protocol. DTP is Dynamic Trunking Protocol and is used to automatically and dynamically build trunks between switches. Multilink PPP is used to load-balance PPP traffic across multiple serial interfaces.

questions.question: What are two load-balancing methods in the EtherChannel technology? (Choose two.)
options: combination of source port and IP to destination port and IP
combination of source MAC and IP to destination MAC and IP
questions.explanation: Depending on the hardware platform, one or more load-balancing methods can be implemented. These methods include source MAC to destination MAC load balancing or source IP to destination IP load balancing, across the physical links.
The multicast MAC address is a special value that begins with 01-00-5E in hexadecimal. lt allows a source device to send a packet to a group of devices.
options: An address that reaches every host inside a local subnet
An address that reaches one specific host
An address that reaches every host in the network
An address that reaches a specific group of hosts
questions.question: What type of address is 01-00-5E-0A-00-02?

questions.explanation: A MAC address is composed of 6 bytes. The first 3 bytes are used for vendor identification and the last 3 bytes must be assigned a unique value within the same OUI.
options: MAC addresses are implemented by software.
A NIC only needs a MAC address if connected to a WAN.
The first three bytes are used by the vendor assigned OUI.
The ISO is responsible for MAC addresses regulations.
questions.question: Which statement is true about MAC addresses?

questions.explanation: Full-duplex communication allows simultaneous transmission and reception, thus no media arbitration is needed. This contrasts with half-duplex, which requires arbitration to manage access to the medium.
questions.question: Which media communication type does not require media arbitration in the data link layer?
What is a recommended best practice when dealing with the native VLAN?
options: Assign the same VLAN number as the management VLAN.
Assign it to an unused VLAN.
questions.explanation: Port security cannot be enabled on a trunk and trunks are the only types of ports that have a native VLAN. Even though turning DTP off on a trunk is a best practice, it does not have anything to do with native VLAN risks. To prevent security breaches that take advantage of the native VLAN, place the native VLAN in an unused VLAN other than VLAN 1. The management VLAN should also be an unused VLAN that is different from the native VLAN and something other than VLAN 1.

questions.question: On what switch ports should PortFast be enabled to enhance STP stability?
options: Only ports that are elected as designated ports
Only ports that attach to a neighboring switch
All trunk ports that are not root ports
questions.explanation: PortFast will immediately bring an interface configured as an access or trunk port to the forwarding state from a blocking state, bypassing the listening and learning states. If configured on a trunk link, immediately transitioning to the forwarding state could lead to the formation of Layer 2 loops. PortFast should only be enabled on end-user (access) ports.

questions.question: Which two commands can be used to enable PortFast on a switch? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: PortFast can be configured on all nontrunking ports using the 'spanning-tree portfast default' global configuration command. Alternatively, PortFast can be enabled on an interface using the 'spanning-tree portfast' interface configuration command.

questions.question: Which feature of 802.11n wireless access points allows them to transmit data at faster speeds than previous versions of 802.11 Wi-Fi standards did?
questions.explanation: Multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technology allows 802.11n devices to use multiple antennas in order to increase the available bandwidth for the wireless network. Single Point Setup (SPS) is a Cisco technology that makes AP deployment easier by supporting clustering from a single management interface. Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS) is used to simplify connecting clients to secure wireless networks. Man-in-the-middle (MITM) is a type of security attack where the attacker attempts to insert themselves into the middle of a data stream.

questions.question: Which parameter is commonly used to identify a wireless network name when a home wireless AP is being configured?
questions.explanation: The SSID is used to name a wireless network. This parameter is required in order for a wireless client to attach to a wireless AP.

questions.question: Which characteristic describes a wireless client operating in active mode?
options: Broadcasts probes that request the SSID
Must be configured for security before attaching to an AP
Must know the SSID to connect to an AP
questions.explanation: A wireless client operating in active mode must know the name of the SSID. Probe requests are broadcast by a client across multiple channels and include the SSID name and supported standards. Active mode is used if an AP is configured to not broadcast beacon frames.

questions.question: Which IEEE standard operates at wireless frequencies in both the 5 GHz and 2.4 GHz ranges?
questions.explanation: The 802.11n standard is backwards compatible with both the 802.11a and 802.11b standards and therefore operates at both 5 GHz and 2.4 GHz.

questions.question: Which statement describes an autonomous access point?
options: It is a standalone access point.
It is used for networks that require a large number of access points.
It is managed by a WLAN controller.
questions.explanation: An autonomous access point is used in environments that require a small number of access points. As network demands increase, more access points can be added to the environment with each access point acting independently of another. An autonomous access point can be configured using either a GUI or CLI.

questions.question: Which two roles are typically performed by a wireless router that is used in a home or small business? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: In addition to its roles as router, a typical SOHO wireless router acts as both a wireless access point and an Ethernet switch. RADIUS authentication is provided by an external server. A WLAN controller is used in enterprise deployments to manage groups of lightweight access points. A repeater is a device that enhances an incoming signal and retransmits it.

questions.question: Which protocol and port numbers are used by both IPv4 and IPv6 CAPWAP tunnels? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: CAPWAP can operate either over IPv4 or IPv6 and can use UDP ports 5246 and 5247. Port 5246 is for data and port 5247 is for control. CAPWAP does not use TCP or ICMP.

questions.question: If three 802.11b access points need to be deployed in close proximity, which three frequency channels should be used? (Choose three.)
questions.explanation: In order to minimize interference, one of the three non-overlapping channels should be used in 2.4GHz Wi-Fi networks: 1, 6, or 11.

questions.question: Which wireless network topology is being configured by a technician who is installing a keyboard, a mouse, and headphones, each of which uses Bluetooth?
questions.explanation: Tethering enables a wireless device such as a phone to provide wireless Internet connectivity to other devices, thus creating a hotspot. Infrastructure mode is the type of wireless network that is created when an access point is being used. Mixed mode allows older wireless NICs to attach to an access point that can use a newer wireless standard. Bluetooth devices operate in ad hoc mode, connecting directly to each other without an access point.

questions.question: Which type of wireless topology is created when two or more Basic Service Sets are interconnected by Ethernet?
questions.explanation: Wireless devices operate in either ad hoc or infrastructure modes. An ad hoc WLAN, also referred to as an independent basic service set (IBISS), operates on a peer-to-peer basis without a network. Infrastructure modes can consist of a single Basic Service Set (BSS) with an AP interconnecting associated stations, or an Extended Service Set (ESS), with two or more BSSes interconnected over a wire distribution system such as Ethernet. WiFi Direct is a compatibility certification unrelated to WLAN topologies.

questions.question: What Wi-Fi management frame is regularly broadcast by APs to announce their presence?
questions.explanation: Beacon frames are broadcast periodically by the AP to advertise its wireless networks to potential clients. Probing, association, and authentication frames are only sent when a client is associating to the AP.

questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. A switch receives a Layer 2 frame that contains a source MAC address of 000b.a023.c501 and a destination MAC address of 0050.0fae.75aa. Place the switch steps in the order they occur.

rightColumn.label: The switch adds the source MAC address to the MAC address table
Because the destination is not known, the switch forwards the frame out all ports except the port through which the frame arrived

questions.explanation: When a switch receives a frame: 1) It first learns the source MAC address and associates it with the incoming port. 2) It then looks up the destination MAC address. If unknown (as in this case where 0050.0fae.75aa is not in the table), it floods the frame to all ports except the source port.

questions.question: Match the DTP mode with its function.

rightColumn.label: Passively waits for the neighbor to initiate trunking
Requires manual configuration of trunking or nontrunking
Actively attempts to convert the link to a trunk

questions.explanation: Dynamic auto passively waits for DTP negotiation. Nonegotiate disables DTP and requires manual trunk configuration. Dynamic desirable actively tries to form a trunk. Trunk mode forces the port into permanent trunk mode regardless of the neighbor.

questions.question: Match the IEEE 802.1Q standard VLAN tag field with the description.

rightColumn.label: A value that supports level or service implementation
A value for the tag protocol ID value
An identifier that enables Token Ring frames to be carried across Ethernet links

questions.explanation: The 802.1Q tag contains: User Priority (3 bits) for QoS/CoS marking, Type field (TPID) identifying the frame as 802.1Q tagged (0x8100), Canonical Format Identifier (CFI) for Token Ring compatibility, and VLAN ID (12 bits) identifying the VLAN number.

questions.question: A network administrator has configured VLAN 99 as the management VLAN and has configured it with an IP address and subnet mask. The administrator issues the show interface vlan 99 command and notices that the line protocol is down. Which action can change the state of the line protocol to up?
options: Connect a host to an interface associated with VLAN 99.
Remove all access ports from VLAN 99.
Configure a transport input method on the vty lines.
questions.explanation: Once an SVI is configured with an IP address and subnet mask, it can be used for remote management. An SVI interface will be active when the SVI VLAN has an active port associated with it.

questions.question: Which statement describes SVIs?
options: An SVI is created automatically for each VLAN on a multilayer switch.
Creating an SVI automatically creates an associated VLAN.
A default SVI is created for VLAN 1 for switch administration.
An SVI can only be created for the management VLAN.
questions.explanation: To allow for remote switch administration, an SVI is created by default for VLAN 1.

questions.question: What is one function of a Layer 2 switch?
options: Forwards data based on logical addressing
Duplicates the electrical signal of each frame to every port
Learns the port assigned to a host by examining the destination MAC address
Determines which interface is used to forward a frame based on the destination MAC address
questions.explanation: A switch builds a MAC address table of MAC addresses and associated port numbers by examining the source MAC address found in inbound frames. To forward a frame onward, the switch examines the destination MAC address, looks in the MAC address for a port number associated with that destination MAC address, and sends it to the specific port. If the destination MAC address is not in the table, the switch forwards the frame out all ports except the inbound port that originated the frame.

questions.question: What will a Cisco LAN switch do if it receives an incoming frame and the destination MAC address is not listed in the MAC address table?
options: Send the frame to the default gateway address.
Use ARP to resolve the port that is related to the frame.
Forward the frame out all ports except the port where the frame is received.
questions.explanation: A LAN switch populates the MAC address table based on source MAC addresses. When a switch receives an incoming frame with a destination MAC address that is not listed in the MAC address table, the switch forwards the frame out all ports except for the ingress port of the frame. When the destination device responds, the switch adds the source MAC address and the port on which it was received to the MAC address table.

questions.question: Which switch characteristic helps alleviate network congestion when a 10 Gbps port is forwarding data to a 1 Gbps port?
questions.explanation: The large frame buffers on a switch hold the ingress traffic until such time that the slower egress port can transmit the data. This reduces the number of dropped frames and alleviates network congestion.

questions.question: Which switching method makes use of the FCS value?
questions.explanation: The store-and-forward method performs error checking on the frame using the frame-check sequence (FCS) value before sending the frame. The FCS value is the last field in the frame.

questions.question: What does the term "port density" represent for an Ethernet switch?
options: The memory space that is allocated to each switch port
The numbers of hosts that are connected to each switch port
questions.explanation: The term port density represents the number of ports available in a switch. A one rack unit access switch can have up to 48 ports. Larger switches may support hundreds of ports.

questions.question: Which information does a switch use to keep the MAC address table information current?
options: The destination MAC address and the incoming port
The destination MAC address and the outgoing port
The source and destination MAC addresses and the incoming port
The source and destination MAC addresses and the outgoing port
The source MAC address and the incoming port
The source MAC address and the outgoing port
questions.explanation: To maintain the MAC address table, the switch uses the source MAC address of the incoming packets and the port that the packets enter. The destination address is used to select the outgoing port.

questions.question: Which type of address does a switch use to build the MAC address table?
questions.explanation: When a switch receives a frame with a source MAC address that is not in the MAC address table, the switch will add that MAC address to the table and map that address to a specific port. Switches do not use IP addressing in the MAC address table.

questions.question: Which option correctly describes a switching method?
options: Cut-through: makes a forwarding decision after receiving the entire frame
Store-and-forward: forwards the frame immediately after examining its destination MAC address
Cut-through: provides the flexibility to support any mix of Ethernet speeds
Store-and-forward: ensures that the frame is free of physical and data-link errors
questions.explanation: Store-and-forward switching performs an error check on an incoming frame after receiving the entire frame on the ingress port. Switches which use this method have the flexibility to support any mix of Ethernet speeds. The cut-through method begins the forwarding process after the destination MAC address of an incoming frame is looked up and the egress port has been determined.

questions.question: What is the purpose of frame buffers on a switch?
options: They provide a basic security scan on received frames.
They provide temporary storage of the frame checksum.
They execute checksum values before transmission.
They hold traffic, thus alleviating network congestion.
questions.explanation: Switches have large frame buffers that allow data waiting to be transmitted to be stored so the data will not be dropped. This feature is beneficial especially if the incoming traffic is from a faster port than the egress port used for transmitting.

questions.question: What happens to a port that is associated with VLAN 10 when the administrator deletes VLAN 10 from the switch?
options: The port goes back to the default VLAN.
The port automatically associates itself with the native VLAN.
The port creates the VLAN again.
questions.explanation: If the VLAN that is associated with a port is deleted, the port becomes inactive and cannot communicate with the network any more. To verify that a port is in an inactive state, use the show interfaces switchport command.

questions.question: In which memory location are the VLAN configurations of normal range VLANs stored on a Catalyst switch?
questions.explanation: When a normal range VLAN is created the configuration information of the VLAN is stored in flash in the vlan.dat file.

questions.question: An administrator is investigating a failure on a trunk link between a Cisco switch and a switch from another vendor. After a few show commands, the administrator notices that the switches are not negotiating a trunk. What is a probable cause for this issue?
options: Both switches are in trunk mode.
Both switches are in nonegotiate mode.
Switches from other vendors do not support DTP.
DTP frames are flooding the entire network.
questions.explanation: DTP is a Cisco proprietary protocol. Non-Cisco switches do not support DTP.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the vlan.dat file on a switch?
questions.explanation: The VLAN database (vlan.dat) contains information about normal range VLANs such as the VLAN number, name, and VTP mode.

questions.question: What is the purpose of setting the native VLAN separate from data VLANs?
options: The native VLAN is for carrying VLAN management traffic only.
The security of management frames that are carried in the native VLAN can be enhanced.
A separate VLAN should be used to carry uncommon untagged frames to avoid bandwidth contention on data VLANs.
The native VLAN is for routers and switches to exchange their management information, so it should be different from data VLANs.
questions.explanation: When a Cisco switch trunk port receives untagged frames (unusual in well-designed networks), it forwards these frames to the native VLAN. When the native VLAN is moved away from data VLANs, those untagged frames will not compete for bandwidth in the data VLANs. The native VLAN is not designed for carrying management traffic, but rather it is for backward compatibility with legacy LAN scenarios.

questions.question: When a Cisco switch receives untagged frames on a 802.1Q trunk port, which VLAN ID is the traffic switched to by default?
questions.explanation: A native VLAN is used to forward untagged frames that are received on a Cisco switch 802.1Q trunk port. Untagged frames that are received on a trunk port are not forwarded to any other VLAN except the native VLAN.

questions.question: A network administrator is determining the best placement of VLAN trunk links. Which two types of point-to-point connections utilize VLAN trunking? (Choose two.)
options: Between two switches that utilize multiple VLANs
Between a switch and a client PC
Between a switch and a server that has an 802.1Q NIC
Between a switch and a network printer
Between two switches that share a common VLAN
questions.explanation: VLAN trunk links are used to allow all VLAN traffic to propagate between devices such as the link between a switch and a server that has an 802.1Q-capable NIC. Switches can also utilize trunk links to routers, servers, and to other switches.

questions.question: What are three primary benefits of using VLANs? (Choose three.)
options: A reduction in the number of trunk links
questions.explanation: Security, cost reduction, and improved IT staff efficiency are all benefits of using VLANs, along with higher performance, broadcast storm mitigation, and simpler project and application management. End users are not usually aware of VLANs, and VLANs do require configuration. Because VLANs are assigned to access ports, they do not reduce the number of trunk links.

questions.question: On a Cisco switch, where is extended range VLAN information stored?
questions.explanation: Extended range VLANs, 1006 through 4094, are not written to the vlan.dat file but are saved in the running configuration file.

questions.question: In which location are the normal range VLANs stored on a Cisco switch by default?
questions.explanation: Normal range VLANs are stored in a file called vlan.dat and located in the flash memory.

questions.question: Which distinct type of VLAN is used by an administrator to access and configure a switch?
questions.explanation: A management VLAN is used to remotely access and configure a switch. Data VLANs are used to separate a network into groups of users or devices. The default VLAN is the initial VLAN all switch ports are placed in when loading the default configuration on a switch. The 802.1Q trunk port places untagged traffic on the native VLAN.

questions.question: For what reason would a network administrator use the show interfaces trunk command on a switch?
options: To examine DTP negotiation as it occurs
To verify port association with a particular VLAN
To display an IP address for any existing VLAN
