It verifies the proper operation of the protocol stack from the network layer to physical layer, without sending a signal on the media. That is, this test does not go beyond the PC itself. For example, it does not detect whether a cable is connected to the PC or not.
options: The PC can access the network. The problem exists beyond the local network.
The IP address obtained from the DHCP server is correct.
The PC can access the Internet. However, the web browser may not work.
questions.question: A user calls to report that a PC cannot access the internet. The network technician asks the user to issue the command ping 127.0.0.1 in a command prompt window. The user reports that the result is four positive replies. What conclusion can be drawn based on this connectivity test?

questions.explanation:
The ping command is the primary utility used to verify Layer 3 connectivity between two network devices. It operates by sending ICMP Echo Request messages to a destination IP address. If the destination is reachable and configured to respond, it replies with ICMP Echo Reply messages.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • netstat: This command is used to display active TCP connections, listening ports, and Ethernet statistics on a local machine, but it does not send echo messages to test remote connectivity.
  • ipconfig: This utility displays the current TCP/IP network configuration values (such as IP address, subnet mask, and default gateway) for a Windows computer.
  • ICMP: While ping uses ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol), ICMP itself is a protocol, not a command. The question specifically asks for a command.
questions.question: Which command can be used to test connectivity between two devices using echo request and echo reply messages?

questions.explanation: ICMPv6 sends a Time Exceeded message if the router cannot forward an IPv6 packet because the packet expired. The router uses a hop limit field to determine if the packet has expired, and does not have a TTL field.
questions.question: What field content is used by ICMPv6 to determine that a packet has expired?

questions.explanation: Topic 13.2.0 - The traceroute command provides connectivity information about the path a packet takes to reach the destination and about every router (hop) along the way. It also indicates how long a packet takes to get from the source to each hop and back.
questions.question: A network administrator can successfully ping the server at www.cisco.com, but cannot ping the company web server located at an ISP in another city. Which tool or command would help identify the specific router where the packet was lost or delayed?

questions.explanation:
In IPv6, the process used to ensure that an IP address is not already in use on the local link is called Duplicate Address Detection (DAD).When an interface becomes active or is assigned a new IPv6 address, it sends an ICMPv6 Neighbor Solicitation (NS) message. The "target address" in this message is the IPv6 address that the host wants to use. If another device on the link is already using that address, it will respond with a Neighbor Advertisement (NA). If no NA is received, the host assumes the address is unique and begins using it.Why the other options are incorrect:
  • ARP request: Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) is used in IPv4 to map IP addresses to MAC addresses. IPv6 replaces ARP functionality with ICMPv6 Neighbor Discovery.
  • Echo request: This is a standard Ping message used to test reachability, not specifically for address uniqueness during the initialization phase.
  • Router solicitation: This message is sent by a host to locate routers on the local link to obtain network prefix information; it is not used for checking address uniqueness.
questions.question: What message is sent by a host to check the uniqueness of an IPv6 address before using that address?

questions.explanation: Subnet 192.168.1.64 /27 has 5 bits that are allocated for host addresses and therefore will be able to support 32 addresses, but only 30 valid host IP addresses. Subnet 192.168.1.96/28 has 4 bits for host addresses and will be able to support 16 addresses, but only 14 valid host IP addresses.
questions.question: A company has a network address of 192.168.1.64 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.192. The company wants to create two subnetworks that would contain 10 hosts and 18 hosts respectively. Which two networks would achieve that? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: Multicast IPv4 addresses use the reserved class D address range of 224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255.
questions.question: Which address prefix range is reserved for IPv4 multicast?

questions.explanation: A mask of 255.255.252.0 is equal to a prefix of /22. A /22 prefix provides 22 bits for the network portion and leaves 10 bits for the host portion. The 10 bits in the host portion will provide 1022 usable IP addresses (2^10 - 2 = 1022).
questions.question: How many host addresses are available on the network 172.16.128.0 with a subnet mask of 255.255.252.0?

questions.explanation: The 172.16.16.0/22 network has 22 bits in the network portion and 10 bits in the host portion. Converting the network address to binary yields a subnet mask of 255.255.252.0. The range of addresses in this network will end with the last address available before 172.16.20.0. Valid host addresses for this network range from 172.16.16.1-172.16.19.254, making 172.16.19.255 the broadcast address.
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. An administrator must send a message to everyone on the router A network. What is the broadcast address for network 172.16.16.0/22?

questions.explanation:
In IPv4, there are two main types of broadcast messages:
  • Limited Broadcast: This uses the destination IP address 255.255.255.255. It is intended for every host on the local network only. Routers do not forward limited broadcasts, so they never leave the originating subnet.
  • Directed Broadcast: This is a message sent to a specific remote network. It uses the broadcast address of that remote subnet (for example, if the remote network is 192.168.10.0/24, the directed broadcast address is 192.168.10.255). Routers forward this packet as a unicast message until it reaches the destination router, which then "explodes" it into a broadcast for that specific local segment.
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • multicast: This is a "one-to-many" message sent to a specific group of devices that have joined a multicast group (e.g., 224.0.0.1), not to all hosts on a network.
  • unicast: This is a "one-to-one" message sent from a single source to a single specific destination IP address.
questions.question: A message is sent to all hosts on a remote network. Which type of message is it?

questions.explanation: To determine the number of bits to borrow for subnetting, use the formula 2^n >= number of required subnets. For five networks, 2^3 = 8 is the smallest power of 2 that accommodates at least five subnets, so three bits are needed.
questions.question: How many bits must be borrowed from the host portion of an address to accommodate a router with five connected networks?

questions.explanation: RFC 1918, Address Allocation for Private Internets, defines three blocks of IPv4 address for private networks that should not be routable an the public Internet. â€¢ 10.0.0.0/8 â€¢ 172.16.0.0/12 â€¢ 192.168.0.0/16.
questions.question: What three blocks of addresses are defined by RFC 1918 for private network use?

questions.explanation:
In IPv6, the prefix (the network portion of the address) is determined by the prefix length (the number after the slash).
  1. Prefix Length: The /64 indicates that the first 64 bits of the address make up the network prefix.
  2. Hextet Breakdown: An IPv6 address is divided into 8 groups of 16 bits each, called hextets, separated by colons.
    • 16 bitsÃ—4 hextets=64 bits
  3. Calculation: To find the prefix, we simply take the first four hextets of the address:
    • Hextet 1: 2001
    • Hextet 2: DB8
    • Hextet 3: BC15
    • Hextet 4: A
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • 2001:DB8:BC15: This only represents the first 48 bits (3 hextets). This is often the Global Routing Prefix assigned by an ISP, but it is not the full /64 network prefix.
  • 2001:DB8:BC15:A:1 / 2001:DB8:BC15:A:12: These include bits from the 5th hextet (12AB), which belongs to the Interface ID (the host portion) in a /64 network.
questions.question: What is the prefix for the host address 2001:DB8:BC15:A:12AB::1/64?

questions.explanation: The explanation is already clear and concise, detailing how a single hexadecimal character allows for 16 different values, thus enabling 16 subnets per sub-site.
questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. A company is deploying an IPv6 addressing scheme for its network. The company design document indicates that the subnet portion of the IPv6 addresses is used for the new hierarchical network design, with the site subsection to represent multiple geographical sites of the company, the sub-site section to represent multiple campuses at each site, and the subnet section to indicate each network segment separated by routers. With such a scheme, what is the maximum number of subnets achieved per sub-site?

questions.explanation: The EUI-64 process uses the MAC address of an interface to construct an interface ID (IID). Because the MAC address is only 48 bits in length, 16 additional bits (FF:FE) must be added to the MAC address to create the full 64-bit interface ID.
options: the MAC address of the IPv6 enabled interface
an IPv6 address that is provided by a DHCPv6 server
an IPv4 address that is configured on the interface
questions.question: What is used in the EUI-64 process to create an IPv6 interface ID on an IPv6 enabled interface?

questions.explanation: IPv6 link-local unicast addresses are in the FE80::/10 prefix range and are not routable. They are used only for communications between devices on the same link.
questions.question: Which IPv6 prefix is reserved for communication between devices on the same link?

questions.explanation: The explanation correctly identifies that moving from a /48 to a /52 prefix creates 16 subnets, with the last being 2001:db8:0:f000::/52.
questions.question: Given IPv6 address prefix 2001:db8::/48, what will be the last subnet that is created if the subnet prefix is changed to /52?

questions.explanation: The IPv6 specifications include anycast addresses. An anycast address is any unicast IPv6 address that is assigned to multiple devices.
questions.question: Which type of IPv6 address refers to any unicast address that is assigned to multiple hosts?

questions.explanation: Multicast, anycast, and unicast are types of IPv6 addresses. However, loopback and link-local are specific types of unicast addresses. There is no broadcast address in IPv6.
questions.question: What are two types of IPv6 unicast addresses? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: This address is one of the assigned IPv6 multicast addresses. Packets addressed to FF02::1 are for all IPv6 enabled devices on the link or network. FF02::2 is for all IPv6 routers that exist on the network.
options: the one IPv6 device on the link that has been uniquely configured with this address
all IPv6 enabled devices on the local link or network
questions.question: An IPv6 enabled device sends a data packet with the destination address of FF02::1. What is the target of this packet?

questions.explanation: When a router sends packets using the traceroute command, it uses the IP address of the interface from which the packet is sent as the source IP address. This behavior can be altered by specifying a different source IP address if needed.
options: the highest configured IP address on the router
the IP address of the outbound interface
the lowest configured IP address on the router
questions.question: What source IP address does a router use by default when the traceroute command is issued?

questions.explanation: 127.0.0.1 is the local loopback address on any TCP/IP network device. By pinging this address, the technician is verifying the TCP/IP protocol stack on that particular device.
options: the TCP/IP stack on a network host
connectivity between two adjacent Cisco devices
connectivity between a PC and the default gateway
connectivity between two PCs on the same network
physical connectivity of a particular PC and the network
questions.question: A technician uses the ping 127.0.0.1 command. What is the technician testing?

questions.explanation:
In IPv6, the Hop Limit field serves the exact same purpose as the Time-to-Live (TTL) field in IPv4. It is an 8-bit field used to prevent packets from looping infinitely on a network.
  1. The Mechanism: When a router receives an IPv6 packet, it decrements the Hop Limit value by 1.
  2. The Drop: If a router receives a packet with a Hop Limit of 1, it decrements it to 0. Because the value is now zero, the router must discard the packet rather than forwarding it.
  3. The Feedback: After dropping the packet, the router sends an ICMPv6 Type 3 (Time Exceeded) message back to the source to inform it that the packet could not reach its destination.
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • A: 255 is the maximum possible value for the Hop Limit. Reaching this value would not cause a packet to be dropped; it would simply be forwarded.
  • C: A router sends the ICMP Time Exceeded message after it drops the packet; it does not drop the original packet because it received an ICMP message.
  • D: An ICMP Echo Reply is generated by the target host, not an intermediate router. This signals a successful "ping" and does not involve dropping the packet due to hop expiration.
options: when the value of the Hop Limit field reaches 255
when the value of the Hop Limit field reaches zero
when the router receives an ICMP time exceeded message
when the target host responds with an ICMP echo reply message
questions.question: A user executes a traceroute over IPv6. At what point would a router in the path to the destination device drop the packet?

questions.explanation: The binary format for 255.255.255.224 is 11111111.11111111.11111111.11100000. The prefix length is the number of consecutive 1s in the subnet mask. Therefore, the prefix length is /27.
questions.question: What is the prefix length notation for the subnet mask 255.255.255.224?

questions.explanation: Multicast is a one-to-many communication where the message is delivered to a specific group of hosts. Broadcast communication is a one-to-all communication. A unicast communication is a one-to-one communication. Anycast is an IPv6 term and is the sending of data in a one-to-nearest communication. When a host transmits a multicast message, it is not sent to all devices on the network (like broadcast), nor is it sent to just one specific host (like unicast). Instead, the multicast message is delivered only to those devices that are members of a special multicast group. These group members have explicitly registered to receive traffic destined to that specific multicast address, typically in the range 224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255 for IPv4 or FF00::/8 for IPv6.
options: a specially defined group of hosts
questions.question: A host is transmitting a multicast. Which host or hosts will receive it?

questions.explanation: The explanation is already clear and correct, detailing the process of compressing IPv6 addresses by removing leading zeros and using '::' for consecutive zero groups.
questions.question: Which is the compressed format of the IPv6 address 2001:0db8:0000:0000:0000:a0b0:0008:0001?

questions.explanation: The code 3 in an ICMPv6 Destination Unreachable message indicates that the destination is beyond the scope of the source address. This means that the source address cannot reach the destination due to scope limitations.
options: communication with the destination administratively prohibited
beyond scope of the source address
questions.question: A user issues a ping fe80:65ab:dcc1::100 command and receives a response that includes a code of 3. What does this code represent?

questions.explanation:
• TCP 3-way handshake: This is the specific process (SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK) used by the Transmission Control Protocol to establish a reliable, connection-oriented session before data is exchanged.
  • UDP: User Datagram Protocol is connectionless, meaning it does not have an "ACK flag" for session establishment or "sequence numbers" in its header for reliability.
  • TCP port number: While used to identify the specific application, the port number itself doesn't establish the session; the handshake does.
questions.question: Which transport layer feature is used to establish a connection-oriented session?

questions.explanation: There are three ranges of TCP and UDP ports. The well-know range of port numbers is from 0 - 1023.
questions.question: What is the complete range of TCP and UDP well-known ports?

questions.explanation: 14.4.0 - A socket is a combination of the source IP address and source port or the destination IP address and the destination port number.
options: The combination of the source and destination IP address and source and destination Ethernet address
The combination of a source IP address and port number or a destination IP address and port number
The combination of the source and destination sequence and acknowledgment numbers
The combination of the source and destination sequence numbers and port numbers
questions.question: What is a socket?

questions.explanation: Each service provided by a server, such as email or file transfers, uses a specific port number. The source port number of a service request identifies the client that is requesting services. The destination port number identifies the specific service. Servers do not use address information to provide services. Routers and switches use addressing information to move traffic through the network.
options: The server sends all requests through a default gateway.
Each request has a combination of source and destination port numbers, coming from a unique IP address.
The server uses IP addresses to identify different services.
Each request is tracked through the physical address of the client.
questions.question: How does a networked server manage requests from multiple clients for different services?

questions.explanation: UDP is a protocol that provides basic transport layer functions with minimal overhead. It is not connection-oriented and does not provide mechanisms for retransmission, sequencing, or flow control. This makes it suitable for applications that are sensitive to delay, such as real-time audio and video streaming, where speed is more critical than reliability.
options: Applications that are sensitive to delay
Applications that require retransmission of lost segments
Applications that are sensitive to packet loss
questions.question: What type of applications are best suited for using UDP?

questions.explanation: The source reduces the number of bytes it sends before receiving an acknowledgment to manage congestion. This is part of TCP's congestion control strategy, which includes mechanisms like slow start and congestion avoidance.
options: The source decreases the amount of data that it transmits before it receives an acknowledgement from the destination.
The source decreases the window size to decrease the rate of transmission from the destination.
The destination decreases the window size.
The destination sends fewer acknowledgement messages in order to conserve bandwidth.
questions.question: Network congestion has resulted in the source learning of the loss of TCP segments that were sent to the destination. What is one way that the TCP protocol addresses this?

questions.explanation: Topic 14.1.0 - Numbering and tracking data segments, acknowledging received data, and retransmitting any unacknowledged data are reliability operations to ensure that all of the data arrives at the destination. UDP does not provide reliability. Both TCP and UDP identify the applications and track individual conversations. UDP does not number data segments and reconstructs data in the order that it is received.
options: Reconstructing data in the order received
questions.question: Which two operations are provided by TCP but not by UDP? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: The source port number in a TCP segment is crucial for identifying and managing multiple simultaneous connections between devices. It helps the operating system distinguish between different data streams and ensures that responses are sent to the correct application.
options: To notify the remote device that the conversation is over
To assemble the segments that arrived out of order
To keep track of multiple conversations between devices
To inquire for a nonreceived segment
questions.question: What is the purpose of using a source port number in a TCP communication?

questions.explanation: Topic 14.6.0 - TCP uses windows to attempt to manage the rate of transmission to the maximum flow that the network and destination device can support while minimizing loss and retransmissions. When overwhelmed with data, the destination can send a request to reduce the of the window. The process of the destination sending acknowledgments as it processes bytes received and the continual adjustment of the source send window is known as sliding windows.
questions.question: What TCP mechanism is used to enhance performance by allowing a device to continuously send a steady stream of segments as long as the device is also receiving necessary acknowledgements?

questions.explanation: Because a session does not have to be established for UDP, the client selects a random source port to begin a connection. The random port number selected is inserted into the source port field of the UDP header.
options: The client sets the window size for the session.
The client sends an ISN to the server to start the 3-way handshake.
The client randomly selects a source port number.
The client sends a synchronization segment to begin the session.
questions.question: Which action is performed by a client when establishing communication with a server via the use of UDP at the transport layer?

questions.explanation: A socket is defined by the combination of an IP address and a port number, and uniquely identifies a particular communication.
questions.question: Which number or set of numbers represents a socket?

questions.explanation: According to Topic 14.1.0, tracking individual conversations is a responsibility of transport layer protocols TCP and UDP.
options: Determining the best path to forward a packet
Translating private IP addresses to public IP addresses
questions.question: What is a responsibility of transport layer protocols?

questions.explanation:
Why these are correct:
  1. Closest to the end user: This is the layer where network-aware applications (like web browsers, email clients, and file transfer programs) reside. It provides the interface through which users interact with the network.
  2. Creation and maintenance of dialogue: Because the TCP/IP Application layer incorporates the OSI "Session" layer functions, it is responsible for initiating, coordinating, and maintaining the dialogue (sessions) between software applications.
Why the other options are wrong:
  • Responsibility for logical addressing: This is a characteristic of the Internet Layer (Layer 3), where IP addresses are used to route packets between networks.
  • Responsibility for physical addressing: This is a characteristic of the Network Access Layer (Layer 1/2), where MAC addresses are used to deliver frames on a local segment.
options: The creation and maintenance of dialogue between source and destination applications
questions.question: What are two characteristics of the application layer of the TCP/IP model? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: HTTP clients send GET messages to request data from web servers.
questions.question: What message type is used by an HTTP client to request data from a web server?

questions.explanation: SMB is used in Microsoft networking environments to facilitate file-sharing and print services. It allows applications to read and write to files and request services from server programs in a computer network.
questions.question: Which application layer protocol is used to provide file-sharing and print services to Microsoft applications?

questions.explanation:
The TCP/IP Application Layer is broad because it encompasses the functions of the top three layers of the OSI model: Application, Presentation, and Session. This means it includes not only the protocols that handle high-level requests (like web browsing) but also the standards that define how data is formatted and presented (like images and video).
  • HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol): A classic application protocol used for web browsing.
  • MPEG (Moving Picture Experts Group): A standard for the compression and presentation of video and audio (OSI Presentation layer function).
  • GIF (Graphics Interchange Format): A standard for image data representation (OSI Presentation layer function).
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • TCP (Transmission Control Protocol): Operates at the Transport Layer. It handles reliability and connection-oriented sessions.
  • UDP (User Datagram Protocol): Operates at the Transport Layer. It handles connectionless, "best-effort" delivery.
  • IP (Internet Protocol): Operates at the Internet Layer. It is responsible for logical addressing and routing packets.
questions.question: Which three protocols or standards are used at the application layer of the TCP/IP model? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: In the client/server network model, a network device assumes the role of server in order to provide a particular service such as file transfer and storage. The device requesting the service assumes the role of client. In the client/server network model, a dedicated server does not have to be used, but if one is present, the network model being used is the client/server model. In contrast, the peer-to-peer network model does not have a dedicated server.
questions.question: An author is uploading one chapter document from a personal computer to a file server of a book publisher. What role is the personal computer assuming in this network model?

questions.explanation: End users interact with the network through applications. The application layer of the TCP/IP model is the topmost layer and is responsible for providing network services directly to the user's applications. It facilitates communication and data exchange between software applications and the network.
questions.question: Which TCP/IP model layer is closest to the end user?

questions.explanation:
For a small- to medium-sized business, IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol) is the preferred choice for retrieving emails because it is designed for server-side storage.
  1. Centralized Storage: Unlike POP, which downloads and usually deletes emails from the server, IMAP keeps the original messages on the mail server. This allows a business to back up its entire email database from a single central location (the server) rather than trying to back up individual employee computers.
  2. Multi-Device Synchronization: Because the mail stays on the server, an employee can check their email on a smartphone, a laptop, and an office desktop, and see the exact same folders and "read/unread" status on every device.
  3. Reliability: If an employee's laptop is stolen or its hard drive fails, no data is lostâ€”the employee simply logs into a new device using IMAP, and all their history is immediately restored from the server.
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • POP (Post Office Protocol): Designed to "download and delete." It moves mail to a single local device, making centralized backup and multi-device access extremely difficult.
  • SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol): Used exclusively for sending (pushing) email, not for retrieving or storing it.
  • HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure): While used to access "Webmail" (like Gmail in a browser), it is a general-purpose web protocol, not a dedicated email retrieval protocol like IMAP.
questions.question: When retrieving email messages, which protocol allows for easy, centralized storage and backup of emails that would be desirable for a small- to medium-sized business?

questions.explanation: Applications that can tolerate some data loss, require a simple request and reply, and handle reliability themselves are best suited for UDP. UDP has low overhead and no requirement of reliability. TCP provides services for reliability, controlling data flow, and the reordering of segments.
options: applications that need data flow control
applications that need the reordering of segments
applications that can tolerate some data loss, but require little or no delay
questions.question: Which two types of applications are best suited for UDP? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: The explanation is already clear and accurate, detailing the use of UDP for client queries and TCP for server-to-server communication.
questions.question: Which protocol or service uses UDP for a client-to-server communication and TCP for server-to-server communication?

questions.explanation: UDP is a connectionless protocol that does not guarantee delivery or order of packets. It reassembles datagrams in the order they are received, not in the order they were sent. This makes it suitable for applications where speed is more critical than reliability.
options: UDP datagrams take the same path and arrive in the correct order at the destination.
Applications that use UDP are always considered unreliable.
UDP reassembles the received datagrams in the order they were received.
UDP only passes data to the network when the destination is ready to receive the data.
UDP has no way to reorder the datagrams into their transmission order, so UDP simply reassembles the data in the order it was received and forwards it to the application.
questions.question: What is a characteristic of UDP?

questions.explanation: With a TCP window size of 1000 bytes, the server can send up to 1000 bytes worth of data before needing an acknowledgment from the PC. Since each segment is 100 bytes, the server will send 10 segments (10 x 100 bytes = 1000 bytes) before requiring an acknowledgment.
questions.question: A PC is downloading a large file from a server. The TCP window is 1000 bytes. The server is sending the file using 100-byte segments. How many segments will the server send before it requires an acknowledgment from the PC?

questions.explanation: The transport layer is responsible for tracking individual communication streams between applications on the source and destination hosts and identifying the proper application for each communication stream through the use of port numbers.
options: identifying the proper application for each communication stream
tracking the individual communication between applications on the source and destination hosts
providing frame delimiting to identify bits making up a frame
performing a cyclic redundancy check on the frame for errors
providing the interface between applications and the underlying network over which messages are transmitted
questions.question: What are two roles of the transport layer in data communication on a network? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: The control bits in the TCP header, such as SYN, ACK, and FIN, are used to establish, maintain, and terminate TCP connections, indicating the status of the three-way handshake process.
questions.question: Which field in the TCP header indicates the status of the three-way handshake process?

questions.explanation: UDP is a connectionless protocol. The client does not establish a connection or check for readiness before sending data. It simply sends the datagrams.
options: It queries the server to see if it is ready to receive data.
It sends a simplified three-way handshake to the server.
It sends to the server a segment with the SYN flag set to synchronize the conversation.
When a client has UDP datagrams to send, it just sends the datagrams.
questions.question: What does a client do when it has UDP datagrams to send?

questions.explanation:
In TCP communication, Window Size is the primary mechanism for Flow Control. It prevents a fast sender from overwhelming a slow receiver by flooding it with more data than it can buffer or process.
  1. The Receiver's Role: The destination host has a finite amount of memory set aside as a receive buffer. As it receives data, it fills this buffer; as the application (like a web browser or file transfer service) processes that data, the buffer empties.
  2. The Advertisement: In every TCP acknowledgment (ACK) it sends back, the destination includes a Window field. This value tells the sender exactly how much space is currently available in that receive buffer.
  3. The Sender's Action: The source is allowed to send up to that "window" worth of data without waiting for another acknowledgment. If the window size drops to zero, the source must stop sending entirely until it receives a window update.
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • A. the amount of data to be transmitted: The total size of a file (e.g., a 100MB video) doesn't dictate the window size; the window size dictates how that 100MB is broken up and flow-controlled during the transfer.
  • B. the number of services included in the TCP segment: TCP segments generally carry data for a single service/application per connection (identified by port numbers). The "number of services" is irrelevant to windowing.
  • C. the amount of data the source is capable of sending: While a sender's hardware limits its maximum speed, it must always throttle its speed down to match what the destination explicitly says it can handle via the window size.
options: the amount of data to be transmitted
the number of services included in the TCP segment
the amount of data the destination can process at one time
the amount of data the source is capable of sending at one time
questions.question: Which factor determines TCP window size?

questions.explanation: The transport layer is responsible for managing the reliability requirements of applications, multiplexing communications of multiple users/applications, and identifying the proper application for each communication stream.
options: meeting the reliability requirements of applications, if any
multiplexing multiple communication streams from many users or applications on the same network
identifying the applications and services on the client and server that should handle transmitted data
directing packets towards the destination network
formatting data into a compatible form for receipt by the destination devices
conducting error detection of the contents in frames
questions.question: What are three responsibilities of the transport layer? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: UDP is a very simple transport layer protocol that does not guarantee delivery. Devices an both ends of the conversation are not required to keep track of the conversation. UDP is used as the transport protocol for applications that need a speedy, best-effort delivery.
options: when applications need to guarantee that a packet arrives intact, in sequence, and unduplicated
when a faster delivery mechanism is needed
when delivery overhead is not an issue
when applications do not need to guarantee delivery of the data
when destination port numbers are dynamic
questions.question: In what two situations would UDP be better than TCP as the preferred transport protocol? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: The sequence number and window fields are part of the TCP header, providing reliability and flow control, which are not features of UDP.
questions.question: Which two fields are included in the TCP header but not in the UDP header? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: The destination and source port numbers are used to identify exactly which protocol and process is requesting or responding to a request.
options: destination and source logical network addresses
The destination and source port numbers are used to identify exactly which protocol and process is requesting or responding to a request.
questions.question: What important information is added to the TCP/IP transport layer header to ensure communication and connectivity with a remote network device?

questions.explanation:
Why these are correct:
  1. Decentralized resources: In a P2P network, files, printers, and processing power are located on the individual "peer" computers rather than being stored in one central location. This makes the network more resilient because there is no "single point of failure."
  2. Resource sharing without a dedicated server: This is the defining feature of P2P. Each device acts as both a client (requesting data) and a server (providing data). You don't need to buy or maintain an expensive, dedicated server for the network to function.
Why the other options are wrong:
  • scalability: While P2P networks can grow, they actually become harder to manage as they get larger because there is no central administration. "Scalability" as a standard positive characteristic usually refers to Client-Server networks where you can simply upgrade the central server to handle more users.
  • one way data flow: P2P is built on two-way communication; every peer both sends and receives data.
  • centralized user accounts: This is a hallmark of a Client-Server network (like a Windows Domain). In P2P, you have to manage user permissions on each individual computer.
options: resource sharing without a dedicated server
questions.question: What are two characteristics of peer-to-peer networks? (Choose two.)

questions.explanation: In the client/server network model, a network device assumes the role of server in order to provide a particular service such as file transfer and storage. In the client/server network model, a dedicated server does not have to be used, but if one is present, the network model being used is the client/server model. In contrast, a peer-to-peer network does not have a dedicated server.
questions.question: Which networking model is being used when an author uploads one chapter document to a file server of a book publisher?

questions.explanation: P2P applications allow the clients to behave as servers if needed. In contrast, with authentication services, email exchange, and client/server applications, one host acts as server and the other acts as client at all times.
questions.question: Which applications or services allow hosts to act as client and server at the same time?

questions.explanation: The application layer of the TCP/IP model combines the functionalities of the session, presentation, and application layers of the OSI model, handling tasks such as data representation, session management, and application services.
questions.question: The application layer of the TCP/IP model performs the functions of what three layers of the OSI model? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: The HTTP GET message is used by a client to request data, such as an HTML page, from a web server. It is one of the most common HTTP methods and is used to retrieve information from the server without making any changes to the data on the server.
options: to request an HTML page from a web server
to send error information from a web server to a web client
to upload content to a web server from a web client
to retrieve client email from an email server using TCP port 110
questions.question: What is the function of the HTTP GET message?

questions.explanation: In a peer-to-peer networking model, each device can act as both a client and a server, allowing direct data exchange without a centralized server. Applications like eDonkey, eMule, BitTorrent, Bitcoin, and LionShare utilize this model to facilitate decentralized communication and resource sharing.
questions.question: In what networking model would eDonkey, eMule, BitTorrent, Bitcoin, and LionShare be used?

questions.explanation: The peer-to-peer (P2P) networking model allows devices to share resources such as files and printers directly with each other without the need for a centralized server.
options: network printing using a print server
resource sharing without a dedicated server

questions.explanation: The explanation is already clear and accurate.
questions.question: Which application layer protocol uses message types such as GET, PUT, and POST?

questions.explanation:
Explanation: The TCP/IP model's Application layer is broader in scope than the OSI model's top layer. It encompasses the functions that the OSI model divides into its top three layers:
  • Application Layer (OSI): Provides the interface between the software application and the network.
  • Presentation Layer (OSI): Handles data formatting, encryption, and compression to ensure that data sent from the application layer of one system can be read by the application layer of another.
  • Session Layer (OSI): Manages the establishment, maintenance, and termination of sessions between applications.
In the TCP/IP suite, these three sets of functions are combined into a single Application layer to simplify the protocol stack for software developers.Incorrect Options:
  • Transport layer: This layer maps directly between both models (e.g., TCP and UDP) and is responsible for end-to-end communication and error recovery.
  • Data link layer / Physical layer: These correspond to the Network Access layer of the TCP/IP model, focusing on hardware addressing and the physical transmission of bits over the medium.
questions.question: Which three layers of the OSI model provide similar network services to those provided by the application layer of the TCP/IP model? (Choose three.)

questions.explanation: The transport layer is responsible for delivering data to the correct application on a device. It uses port numbers to differentiate between multiple applications running on the same device, ensuring data is sent to the correct application.
options: A student is using a classroom VoIP phone to call home. The unique identifier burned into the phone is a transport layer address used to contact another network device on the same network.
A student is playing a short web-based movie with sound. The movie and sound are encoded within the transport layer header.
A student has two web browser windows open in order to access two web sites. The transport layer ensures the correct web page is delivered to the correct browser window.

A corporate worker is accessing a web server located on a corporate network. The transport layer formats the screen so the web page appears properly no matter what device is being used to view the web site.
The source and destination port numbers are used to identify the correct application and window within that application.
questions.question: Which scenario describes a function provided by the transport layer?

questions.explanation: After receiving two packets of 1500 bytes each, the web server will have received a total of 3000 bytes. The acknowledgment number indicates the next byte expected, which is 6001, not 3001.
questions.question: A PC that is communicating with a web server has a TCP window size of 6,000 bytes when sending data and a packet size of 1,500 bytes. Which byte of information will the web server acknowledge after it has received two packets of data from the PC?

questions.explanation: Redundancy is a key consideration in network design for large corporations to ensure continuous operation and minimize downtime. Small businesses may not prioritize redundancy due to cost constraints and simpler network needs.

questions.explanation: Topic 17.1.0 - In a small business with a large growth forecast, the primary influencing factor would be the ability of devices to support modularity. Devices with a fixed type/number of interfaces would not support growth. Redundancy is an important factor, but typically found in large enterprises. Network monitoring is also an important consideration, but not as important as modularity.
options: Devices with a fixed number and type of interfaces
Devices that have support for network monitoring
questions.question: A newly hired network technician is given the task of ordering new hardware for a small business with a large growth forecast. Which primary factor should the technician be concerned with when choosing the new devices?

The traceroute command is used to initiate a trace from a Cisco router or switch. Some other PC operating systems, such as Linux and Mac OS also use the traceroute command. questions.explanation: Topic 17.3.0 - To scale a network, several elements are required: - Network documentation - physical and logical topology - Device Inventory - list of devices that use or make up the network - Budget - Itemized IT budget, including fiscal year equipment purchasing budget - Traffic analysis - protocols, applications, and services and their respective traffic requirements should be documented

questions.explanation: Small networks generally have only one link to an ISP to establish a connection to the Internet. Problems can occur in the network, which can cause the disruption of this service. In order to keep connectivity, redundancy has to be provided. If the problem is in the router interface that is connected to the ISP, another Interface can be activated an the router, so if one interface falls, traffic may be redirected toward the other interface. However, if the router itself falls, a second router that is connected to another ISP can be used as a backup.
options: Activate another router interface that is connected to the ISP, so the traffic can flow through it.
Have a second router that is connected to another ISP.
Purchase a second least-cost link from another ISP to connect to this router.
Add more interfaces to the router that is connected to the internal network.

At the lowest point of traffic in the network
At regular intervals over a period of time

FCS (Frame Check Sequence) and SFD (Start Frame Delimiter) are fields of the Ethernet frame. CSMA (Carrier Sense Multiple Access) is the technology Ethernet uses to manage shared media access.

questions.explanation: The purpose of an ARP request is to find the MAC address of the destination host on an Ethernet LAN. The ARP process sends a Layer 2 broadcast to all devices on the Ethernet LAN. The frame contains the IP address of the destination and the broadcast MAC address, FFFF.FFFF.FFFF. The host with the IP address that matches the IP address in the ARP request will reply with a unicast frame that includes the MAC address of the host. Thus the original sending host will obtain the destination IP and MAC address pair to continue the encapsulation process for data transmission.
options: the physical address of the destination host

questions.explanation:
Explanation: The IPv6 address ::1/128 is designated as the loopback address. It is the IPv6 functional equivalent of the IPv4 address 127.0.0.1.
  • Purpose: It is used by a node to send an IPv6 packet to itself. This is primarily used for testing the TCP/IP stack functionality on the local device.
  • Format: It consists of 127 zeros followed by a single 1. In its compressed form, it is written as ::1.
  • Scope: Packets with this destination address must never be sent over a physical link and must never be forwarded by a router.
Incorrect Options:
  • unspecified: Represented as ::/128 (all zeros). It indicates the absence of an address and is typically used as a source address in specialized packets like Duplicate Address Detection (DAD) neighbor solicitations.
  • global unicast: These are publicly routable addresses, similar to public IPv4 addresses. They typically start with the binary prefix 001 (represented in hex as 2000::/3).
  • EUI-64 generated link-local: Link-local addresses always begin with the prefix fe80::/10. When generated via EUI-64, the interface's 48-bit MAC address is expanded into a 64-bit interface identifier by inserting ff:fe in the middle and flipping the seventh bit.
questions.question: What type of IPv6 address is represented by ::1/128?

questions.explanation: The IPv6 address fe80:0000:0000:0000:0220:0b3f:f0e0:0029 can be compressed by removing leading zeros in each hextet and replacing a single, longest sequence of consecutive zero hextets with a double colon ::. Therefore, fe80:0000:0000:0000:0220:0b3f:f0e0:0029 becomes fe80::220:b3f:f0e0:29.
questions.question: Which is the compressed format of the IPv6 address fe80:0000:0000:0000:0220:0b3f:f0e0:0029?

questions.explanation: In the IPv6 address scheme, the network of fe80::/10 is reserved for link-local addresses. The address fe80::/64 is a network address that indicates, in this workstation, fe80::/64 is actually used for link-local addresses. Thus the address fe80::30d0:115:3f57:fe4d128 is a valid IPv6 link-local address.
